prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

responses.text:
“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

I slam my notebook shut, cheeks burning. The hallway echoes with his cackling as he bursts into my room, phone camera already rolling. “Smile for the family group chat!”

I lunge for the phone, but he’s too quick. “Seriously, Max, get out!”

He ducks behind my beanbag, grinning. “You’re the one who told Mom you’d babysit. Brad can’t help it if he’s popular.”

I groan. Upstairs, Brad’s music thumps through the ceiling. The walls vibrate with giggles and the occasional thud. My homework deadline looms, but all I can focus on is the humiliation Max’s video will bring.

Suddenly, footsteps thunder down the stairs. Brad, shirtless and wild-eyed, appears in the doorway. “MAX!”

Max’s face drains of color. “Gotta run!” He sprints out, tripping over his own feet.

Brad sighs. “Sorry, little bro.”

I shake my head. “It’s fine. But maybe next time, warn me before you invite the circus home?”

He grins. “Deal.”

And as the door closes, I can’t help but laugh. Maybe chaos is just another word for family.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

I peek through the crack in my bedroom door, watching as Derek, my little brother, hollers down the hallway with glee. Mom’s footsteps thunder up the stairs. I groan—every time Brad brings over a girlfriend, Derek turns into the town crier.

When Mom bangs on Brad’s door, there’s a flurry of motion inside. I hear muffled voices, a scramble, and then silence. Derek, sensing the drama, slinks back towards me, grinning like a hyena.

“You’re the worst,” I mutter.

He shrugs. “Someone’s gotta keep things interesting around here.”

When Brad finally opens his door, hair askew and cheeks red, Mom’s expression is pure mortification. Brad’s girlfriend slips out behind him, avoiding eye contact. I almost feel bad for them—almost.

Later, when the house has settled, Derek plops down next to me. “You think you’ll ever get to embarrass Brad as much as I do?”

I shake my head, smiling despite myself. “Not a chance. That’s your superpower.”

He beams. “Don’t worry, I’ll teach you.”

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

I clutch the edge of my desk, mortified. Of course, Tyler couldn't just text me—he had to bellow it down the hallway for everyone to hear. The whole house freezes for a second, as if the words themselves are a bomb.

Mom pokes her head out of the kitchen. “What did you just say?”

Tyler grins like he’s won a prize. “Brad’s got company,” he says, waggling his eyebrows. I wish the ground would swallow me whole. My older brother, oblivious, probably thinks he’s smooth.

I glare at Tyler. “Do you have to be like this?”

He shrugs. “I live to torment you.”

The worst part? He really does. But as the evening turns awkward, I realize something: maybe I don’t have to let him ruin everything. I grab my headphones and crank up my favorite playlist, blocking out the chaos. Tyler keeps snickering, but this time, I don’t care. For once, I’m in control of my own embarrassment—and that feels kind of great.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

I freeze, cereal spoon halfway to my mouth. The words echo through the house, bouncing off the walls like a pinball. My mother drops her mug. My father’s newspaper crumples. Silence, then chaos.

I glare at my little brother, who grins, proud of himself. He lives for this—dragging my reputation through the mud, one family breakfast at a time.

Mom rushes upstairs. “BRAD! What’s going on?”

I sigh. Across the table, my brother shrugs, utterly unrepentant. “You said you wanted things to be more exciting,” he whispers.

From above, muffled protests and slamming doors. Dad sighs, folding his newspaper. “Kids these days.”

I meet my brother’s eyes, and for a moment, I wonder if I’ll ever get him back for this. Probably not. But maybe, someday, I’ll find a way to embarrass him just as badly. Until then, I just keep eating my cereal, praying for normalcy—and knowing it’ll never come as long as he’s around.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

It’s not enough that he says it once—no, he has to shout it, running up and down the stairs like he’s the town crier and Brad’s escapades are headline news. The walls vibrate with his glee. I slam my bedroom door, but it doesn’t matter. Nothing is safe from the disaster that is my little brother.

Mom yells from the kitchen, “What did you say, Toby?” Brad’s door upstairs slams. I can picture the mortified look on his face, the way he’ll glare at me later as if it’s my fault our brother can’t keep a secret.

Toby finally bursts into my room, breathless. “Did you hear that? He’s in so much trouble!”

I roll my eyes. “You need a hobby.”

He grins. “Embarrassing you is my hobby.”

And as chaos erupts upstairs, I realize I’m not mad. Not really. It’s just another day in the house of perpetual embarrassment—a circus I didn’t choose, but one I guess I wouldn’t trade for anything.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice echoing in the empty alley. I hesitate, clutching my bag close. The city is not a kind place after midnight, and strangers can be dangerous shadows. Yet something about the man's trembling hands and pleading eyes pulls at me. I step closer, wary. He points to a crumpled piece of paper at his feet. "My son," he whispers, "I lost him. I can't remember where he lives."

I pick up the paper. An address, smudged by rain. The man looks at me, hope flickering in his gaze. Against my better judgment, I take his arm gently. "Come on," I say, "let's go find him."

We walk together through the sleeping city. The old man tells me stories of a life lived in shadows and light. When we finally reach the address, a young man opens the door, eyes wide in relief. The old man beams. I realize I was never in danger—except of missing a story worth hearing.

"Help me,” the old man repeats. His eyes dart between the shadows gathering at the edge of the abandoned train station. I hesitate. The air is thick with rain and secrets, but something in his tone—urgent, desperate—roots me to the spot.

He grabs my sleeve. "They took it. My memory. My name."

I swallow hard. "Who did?"

He shivers, clutching his threadbare coat. "The men in gray. They said I had seen too much. That I would forget. But I remember you."

A chill runs through me. I search his face, finding nothing familiar. "You must be mistaken."

He shakes his head. "No. You promised. You said you'd help me remember."

Thunder rumbles, the train tracks humming with an oncoming storm. I realize I've been here before, in dreams I can't recall. The old man's grip tightens, and I understand—some promises chase us, even when forgotten.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his words trembling with fear. I look around the deserted street, wondering if anyone else can hear him. His clothes are tattered, but his eyes are sharp and clear, as if he’s seen something I cannot.

"What do you need?" I ask, approaching slowly.

He points to a flickering streetlamp. "There’s something wrong with the light. It’s listening."

I blink in confusion. "The light?"

He nods urgently. "They come when it goes out. I can’t remember who they are, but they always come. Please, don’t let it go dark."

I stare at the lamp, its glow wavering. My skepticism battles my curiosity. As the bulb sputters, a cold wind whips around us. The old man’s grip tightens on my sleeve.

"Promise me," he whispers. "Promise you’ll keep the light on."

I nod, feeling the world shift beneath my feet, as if the darkness is waiting for us to forget.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice barely more than a whisper. His gnarled fingers clutch the rusted gate as I pass by, the chill of autumn swirling around us. I pause, uncertain.

He looks up, eyes shimmering with something like fear. "Please. I need to find the tree. The one with the red ribbon."

I glance toward the tangled woods beyond the gate. A memory tugs at me: a legend of a tree that grants wishes once every hundred years, marked by a crimson ribbon.

"Why do you need the tree?" I ask.

He sighs, shoulders sagging. "I made a promise to someone long ago. Tonight is the last chance."

I hesitate, then push open the gate. Together, we step into the bramble, guided by moonlight and hope. The woods seem to breathe, alive with secrets. Somewhere ahead, a ribbon flutters, red as a heart, and the old man squeezes my hand, gratitude shining in his tired eyes.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice echoing through the cold, empty park. I stop, glancing at my watch. I’m late already, but something about his words tugs at me.

"What’s wrong?" I ask, kneeling beside his bench.

He looks up with haunted eyes. "They’re coming. The shadows. I can’t outrun them anymore."

I shiver, telling myself it’s just the wind. "Who’s coming?"

He grabs my hand with surprising strength. "Promise me you’ll remember my name. If you do, they can’t take me."

I search his face, but he never says his name. Instead, the lights around us flicker, and the night deepens. I try to reassure him, but the words evaporate in the mist.

When I look again, the old man is gone. Only a scrap of paper remains on the bench, a name written in hurried script. I clutch it tightly, knowing I’ll never forget.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats. His voice, gravelly but urgent, echoes across the abandoned train platform. I hesitate, my backpack heavy with stolen bread and a racing heart. He’s hunched on the bench, a map clutched in shaking hands, eyes clouded but pleading. 

I glance left and right—no one else is coming. Wariness pulses in my chest, but I step closer. "What do you need?" I whisper.

His fingers tremble as he unfolds the map, pointing to a spot circled in red. "The safe house. I can’t walk much farther. My granddaughter... she’s waiting there."

The city curfew siren wails in the distance. If I help him, I risk everything. But the old man’s eyes remind me of my own grandfather, lost last winter to the cold. I sigh, offering my arm. Together, we shuffle toward the edge of the platform, shadows stretching long behind us. As we disappear into the night, I realize I’ve chosen hope over safety—a dangerous, necessary kindness in a world that’s forgotten both.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His frail hand clutches the edge of the weathered oak counter, knuckles white. The antique shop is empty except for the two of us and the faint ticking of a hundred forgotten clocks. I hesitate, unsure if he means to ask for a glass of water or something more profound.

He leans forward, eyes wide and watery, and whispers, "The clocks. They’re all wrong. Can you hear them?" My skin prickles. I listen. The ticking isn’t synchronized. Some run backward, others stutter, and one emits a hollow chime that seems to echo inside my chest.

"I tried fixing them," he says, voice cracking. "But they remember too much. They want to go back."

I reach for the nearest clock, feeling a chill as my fingers graze the brass rim. The hands spin wildly before freezing at midnight. The shop grows colder. The old man’s gaze is fixed on me, desperate.

With trembling hands, I begin to wind the clocks, one by one, as outside, night falls and time itself seems to fracture.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His voice is soft, barely audible above the howling wind that sweeps through the alley. I almost walk past him, huddled in a threadbare coat, but something in the way he looks at me roots my feet to the pavement.

He lifts a trembling hand, revealing a crumpled photograph—two children, smiling in the sunlight, a world away from this cold night. "I lost them," he whispers, his voice cracking. "My memories... they’re fading."

I kneel beside him, uncertain, but drawn by the sorrow in his eyes. "Tell me about them," I say. He smiles, a fragile thing, and begins to speak. As he talks, the darkness seems to recede, the alley filling with the warmth of his stories. Names, laughter, places I’ve never seen come alive in the frosty air.

When his tale ends, the old man presses the photograph into my hand. "Remember for me," he pleads. I nod, promising to carry his memories forward. By dawn, he is gone, but his stories remain, lighting the way through my own lonely nights.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His hands shake as he lifts a battered suitcase onto the bus stop bench. Rain streaks down the glass shelter, blurring the city lights beyond. I consider ignoring him—everyone else does—but something about the fear in his eyes makes me pause.

"What do you need?" I ask, keeping my distance. 

He fumbles with the suitcase, popping the latches. Inside, instead of clothes, I see hundreds of folded paper cranes, each delicately inked with strange symbols. He pulls one out, pressing it into my palm. "If you see her, give her this," he whispers. "She’ll know what it means."

Before I can ask who, the bus arrives. The old man boards, leaving me with the crane. I watch the taillights vanish into the night and shiver, feeling the weight of the message in my hand. Somewhere in the city, a story waits to be finished. I tuck the crane into my jacket and start walking, rain tapping out a secret code on the pavement.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His eyes dart around the crowded market, seeking a friendly face. I hesitate, not wanting to get involved, but his desperation is palpable. He extends a trembling hand toward me, clutching a small, velvet pouch.

"They’re after me," he whispers. "You must keep this safe. Promise?"

Before I can answer, he presses the pouch into my palm and vanishes into the throng. I glance inside—there’s a single, iridescent marble, swirling with colors I’ve never seen before. Suddenly, two men in dark coats appear, scanning the crowd, their gaze sharp and searching.

A cold sweat breaks on my forehead. I slip the pouch into my pocket and melt into the mass of shoppers, heart pounding. Who was that old man? What have I gotten myself into?

As I hurry away, the marble grows warm against my skin. A faint voice, not the old man’s, whispers in my ear: "Run."

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice trembling as he clings to the frayed edges of his faded coat. I hesitate on the threshold, the evening fog curling around my ankles. No one else seems to hear him. The street is empty, save for the distant glow of a bakery sign and the echo of my own footsteps. 

He looks up at me, eyes wide and pleading. "They took my memories," he whispers, "I can't find my way home."

I reach out, uncertain, but drawn by something in his gaze. He presses a small, intricately carved wooden box into my hand. "Open this by moonlight. Only then will you know."

The wind picks up, rustling papers at our feet. When I glance down to steady the box, the old man is gone. My heart pounds as I clutch the box, feeling the weight of a mystery I never expected to inherit.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his gnarled fingers clutching the park bench as if it were the only thing tethering him to the earth. The rain falls in slow, heavy drops, soaking through the thin fabric of his coat. I pause, uncertain; the city has taught me to be wary, but something in his eyes—wild, desperate—draws me closer. 

"What do you need?" I ask, voice barely audible over the patter of rain.

He looks at me, and for a moment, I see a flicker of hope. "There's a key," he whispers. "In the fountain."

Without another word, he slumps forward, exhausted. I glance at the old stone fountain nearby, its basin glimmering with coins and secrets. My curiosity outweighs my caution. I cross the slick stones, searching for the key, wondering what doors it might unlock—and why the old man trusted me to find it.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice echoing off the crumbling walls of the abandoned subway station. He stands in the shadows, wrapped in a moth-eaten cloak, eyes flickering in the dim light. I hesitate, a chill running down my spine.

"What do you need?" I ask, my voice barely a whisper. 

He gestures toward a rusted trapdoor at his feet. "Down there. Something waits for me. It won’t let me leave."

Despite my fear, I step closer. The air grows colder, thick with the scent of earth and dust. The old man’s hand trembles as he offers me a tarnished lantern. I take it, heart pounding, and lift the trapdoor. Darkness yawns below, deep and endless.

I glance back, but the old man is gone. Only his voice remains, echoing in the gloom: "Help me."

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice barely more than a whisper, eyes darting between the shadows in the alley. He clutches a battered suitcase to his chest. I glance over my shoulder, uncertain if I should get involved, but the desperation in his trembling hands is undeniable.

He leans closer, breath sharp with fear. "They’re watching. It’s not safe here."

Before I can respond, he thrusts the suitcase at me. "Take this. Don’t open it. Not until you reach the river."

I stammer, confused, but he’s already limping away, melting into the darkness. The suitcase is heavier than it looks, and my fingers tingle where I touch the handle. I look down the alley, heart racing, and wonder what I’ve just agreed to—and who, or what, might be following me now.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his hands shaking as he grips the iron bars of the church gate. The night is cold, and the street is empty except for the dim glow from the stained glass windows. I step forward, unsure if I should get involved. His eyes—wide, haunted—meet mine. "They won’t let me rest."

A gust of wind rattles the branches overhead. He shuffles aside, revealing a faded envelope pressed against his chest. "Take this to the bell tower," he pleads, voice quivering. "Only then will they leave me be."

Against my better judgment, I take the envelope. The paper is brittle, the wax seal broken. I glance back, but the old man is gone—vanished into the night. As I stand alone, the church bells begin to toll, and I realize I may have stumbled into something far older, and more dangerous, than I imagined.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice barely more than a croak. I hesitate on the threshold of the abandoned train station, rain seeping through the shattered roof and pooling around my shoes. His eyes are fixed on the shadows lurking beyond the platform, not on me. "Please, they're coming."

I want to run, but something pins me in place. The old man’s trembling hand clutches at my sleeve. "You have to listen. The train... it’s not what it seems."

Lightning splits the sky, illuminating the rusted tracks. From somewhere deep in the tunnels, a metallic screech echoes. I swallow, heart pounding. "Who’s coming?"

He shakes his head, eyes wild. "Not who. What."

Suddenly, a cold wind rushes past us, carrying with it the faintest hint of a whisper. The old man tightens his grip. "If you value your soul, you’ll help me stop it."

I look into the darkness, where something moves with impossible speed. My courage flickers, but I nod. Whatever nightmare this man has stumbled upon, I realize, I’m now a part of it.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His trembling fingers clutch a faded leather-bound book, its pages yellowed and brittle. I glance around the crowded park, but no one else seems to notice him. 

He looks at me with watery blue eyes, desperation etched into every wrinkle. "They said you'd understand," he whispers. "You see them too, don't you?"

A chill runs down my spine. I follow his gaze and spot, just for a moment, a flickering shadow at the edge of the fountain—gone as soon as I try to focus. 

"What do you want me to do?" I ask, voice hushed.

"Take the book," he insists, thrusting it into my hands. "Guard it. Promise me."

Against all reason, I nod. When I look up, the old man is gone, vanished into the crowd. I clutch the book to my chest, heart racing, and notice a strange symbol etched on the cover. As the sun sets, the shadows stretch, and I suddenly feel very, very watched.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His voice trembles, echoing through the silent alleyway. He’s slumped against a crumbling brick wall, a torn coat wrapped tight around bony shoulders. I glance behind me, uncertain. The streetlights flicker, casting long shadows that seem to breathe.

"Please," he whispers, eyes wide. "They took my shadow."

I freeze. "Your...shadow?"

He nods, pointing with a shaking finger. Sure enough, beneath his feet, there’s only cold pavement—no shadow clings to him, though the light shines directly from above. I step closer, curiosity overtaking fear. “How? Who did this?”

A shiver crawls up my spine as a low, inhuman chuckle echoes from the darkness. The old man grabs my wrist, grip surprisingly strong. "Don’t let them take yours, too," he rasps. "Run, before it’s too late."

I hesitate, then turn to flee, heart racing. Behind me, the alley seems to swallow the old man whole, his warning lingering in the night. I don’t stop running until dawn paints the city gold.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His beard is tangled, his eyes clouded with something I can’t name. He’s sitting on a bench by the river, clutching a small wooden box to his chest. 

I hesitate, unsure. People pass by, glancing but not stopping. The air is thick with the scent of rain. "Please," he says, voice cracking, "they’re coming for this. You must keep it safe. Don’t open it. Promise me."

Before I can answer, he thrusts the box into my hands, his gnarled fingers cold against my skin. I look down at it, feeling a strange warmth pulsing from within. I look up to ask what he means, but he’s gone—vanished into the mist rising from the river. 

As I stand there, alone, the box begins to vibrate. Something inside whispers my name. Against my better judgment, curiosity grows. The old man’s plea echoes in my mind: Don’t open it. But the urge is overwhelming. 

I take a breath, and slowly, I lift the lid.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His hands, gnarled and stained with earth, tremble as he grips the edge of the well. I hesitate, glancing at the tangled forest behind him, unsure if I should approach. The sky is bruised with twilight, and the air smells of moss and something old, hidden.

"What’s wrong?" I ask, voice barely above a whisper.

He shudders, his eyes darting to the water below. "She’s down there. My granddaughter. The well took her."

A chill pools in my stomach. "The well?"

He nods, desperate. "It’s hungry. Every seven years. Please, you must help me bring her back."

Against my better judgment, I peer into the darkness. The water’s surface is still, but deep below, something moves—a pale shape drifting, eyes wide and unblinking. A cold hand brushes mine. I gasp, but the old man only nods, tears streaming down his face.

"Don’t let it take you too," he whispers, as the well’s shadow pulls me in.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text: "Help me," the old man repeats, his voice thin as a reed, echoing against the rain-streaked alley walls. I hesitate, clutching my groceries, the city’s bustle blurring behind me. He sits hunched, rain pooling in the folds of his threadbare coat, eyes flickering with something desperate and ancient. I kneel, unsure, and he grasps my wrist with surprising strength. His hand is cold, his nails rimmed with dirt. "They’re coming," he whispers. "Not for me. For you." The city’s noise seems to hush, my heart skipping. "Who?" I manage. He leans closer, breath sour, gaze wild. "Listen for the song. When you hear it, run." Then, as suddenly as he appeared, he lets go. I stagger backwards, the world snapping back into focus: the cars, the rain, the neon. But later that night, as I lie awake, I hear it—a distant, haunting melody drifting through my open window, and my blood runs cold.

"Help me," the old man repeats. His voice is little more than a rasp, but urgent. I pause on the cracked sidewalk, uncertain whether to step forward or keep walking. It's nearly midnight, the streetlamp flickering above us. He clutches a battered suitcase, his eyes darting to the darkened alley behind. "They took everything," he murmurs. "But not this." He fumbles open the suitcase, revealing a single, gleaming feather—iridescent, shifting in color with the faintest light. "They’ll come for it," he warns, pressing it into my hands. His grip is trembling. "Take it far from here. Promise me." I nod, bewildered. A shout echoes from the alley. Before I can ask anything more, the old man limps away, vanishing into the shadows. I stand, clutching the feather to my chest, as strange footsteps approach from the darkness.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his trembling hands reaching out through the fog. I hesitate, backpack slung awkwardly on my shoulder, glancing at the empty street behind me. "Please," he croaks, lowering himself to the curb. I step closer, heart thudding. "What do you need?" I ask. His eyes glisten, desperate. "My memories," he whispers. "They’re slipping away. You—can you find them?" Confused, I kneel. His fingers brush my forehead, and suddenly, I see flashes: a riverbank, laughter, a red kite soaring. I gasp, feeling memories not my own flooding in. "Bring them back," he pleads. "Or I’ll be lost." I squeeze his hand, promising to help. As dawn breaks, I wander the city, seeking the faces and places from his mind, hoping to return what time has stolen.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his eyes darting between the shadows that stretch across the abandoned train station. I hesitate, unsure if I should approach, but his voice—cracked and pleading—pulls me forward. He clutches a tattered notebook to his chest, its pages fluttering in the wind. "They want my secrets," he whispers, glancing nervously over his shoulder. "If they find me, it's over. But you... maybe you can finish what I started." He thrusts the notebook into my hands, his fingers icy. "Promise me you'll read it." Before I can respond, he disappears into the darkness, leaving only the echo of his footsteps. I look down at the notebook, feeling the weight of unseen eyes. Somewhere, in the pages, a story waits—a story someone will do anything to keep hidden.

"Help me," the old man repeats, his voice trembling as he clings to the edge of the splintered dock. The lake, black and silent, laps hungrily at his boots. I freeze, unsure, but his gaze holds me. "They’re down there," he says, pointing a shaking finger at the water. "I tried to warn them, but no one listened." Lightning crackles above, momentarily illuminating the shape of something just beneath the surface. My breath catches. "What’s down there?" I ask, but he only shakes his head, eyes wide with fear. A chill runs through me as I realize the ripples spreading from the dock aren’t caused by the wind. Suddenly, the old man’s grip slips. I lunge to help, but he’s gone—swallowed whole by the lake, leaving only silence and my own reflection, staring back in terror.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Help me,” the old man repeats.

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice barely more than a whisper against the howling wind. I hesitate, glancing over my shoulder at the empty road behind us. The streetlights flicker, casting long shadows across the pavement. The old man clutches a faded photograph in his trembling hand, eyes pleading. “They’ll find me if I stay here.”

I step closer, careful not to startle him. “Who’s after you?” I ask, trying to sound calm. The old man’s lips quiver, but he says nothing. Instead, he presses the photograph into my palm. It’s a picture of a smiling woman and a little girl. On the back, scrawled in shaky handwriting: ‘Find them before the clock strikes twelve.’

A chill runs down my spine. I glance at the glowing face of my watch—eleven-thirty. The old man’s eyes dart to the shadows. “Please,” he says, “they don’t have much time.”

I nod, tucking the photograph into my pocket. Together, we slip into the darkness, the old man’s desperate plea echoing in the night.

"Help me,” the old man repeats, clutching the tattered suitcase to his chest. His eyes dart around the deserted train station, searching for someone—anyone—who might listen. I hesitate, wary after the stories I’d heard about this place, but something in his quavering voice draws me closer.

He beckons me with a trembling hand. “They took everything,” he whispers. “But they couldn’t take this.” He gestures to the suitcase. I peer down and notice strange symbols burned into the leather. The air feels suddenly colder.

“Who are you?” I ask, my voice low.

He shakes his head. “No time. You must hide this. Promise me.”

Before I can reply, a shadow flickers at the edge of the platform. The old man shoves the suitcase into my arms. “Run,” he says, his voice urgent now. “And no matter what, don’t open it—not until midnight.”

As the station lights flicker and die, I clutch the suitcase and run, chased by questions—and the growing certainty that I’m now part of something far bigger than I understand.

"Help me,” the old man repeats, his gnarled fingers clutching the wrought-iron fence. The garden behind him brims with wild roses, their scent oddly sharp in the midnight air. I had only meant to cut through the alley, but his voice, fragile and insistent, anchors my feet to the spot.

He gestures toward the tangled blossoms. “They won’t let me leave,” he says, his voice trembling. “Not until someone listens.”

I peer past the gate, expecting to see someone, but there is only the rustle of petals and the silver gleam of the moon. “Who?” I ask, my own voice barely audible.

He looks up, his eyes reflecting a desperate hope. “The roses,” he whispers. “They remember.”

I reach out to help him, and as my hand brushes his, the roses begin to quiver. Petals swirl up, forming shapes—faces, hands, memories. The old man’s story spills forth in a torrent of scent and sorrow, and I realize that, tonight, helping him may mean listening to the garden’s secrets until dawn.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, voice cracking like dry leaves. I pause, torn between instinct and caution. He’s standing at the edge of the woods, cloak tattered, eyes shining with something wild. His hands shake as he gestures for me to come closer. 

Reluctantly, I approach. “What’s wrong?” I ask.

He glances over his shoulder into the trees. “They’re coming. I tried to warn them, but nobody listened.”

A chill creeps up my spine. The woods are silent, not even the chirp of a bird. “Who’s coming?”

The old man’s lips move, but no sound comes out. Suddenly, a low hum vibrates through the ground, and the trees begin to sway, though there’s no wind. From the darkness, pale shapes emerge, shifting and fluid.

“Take this,” he rasps, pressing a cold, heavy key into my palm. “It’s the only way.” Before I can speak, he’s gone, swallowed by the shadows. Now, alone with the key and the approaching shapes, I realize I must decide: run, or follow the old man’s warning into the heart of the woods.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, his eyes glassy and unfocused as he stumbles into the flickering light of the laundromat. The machines drone on, indifferent, as he grips the edge of a folding table to steady himself. 

I glance around, wondering if someone more qualified should intervene, but there’s no one else—just me and the hum of dryers. I approach, hesitant. “Are you hurt?”

He shakes his head, breath rasping. “It’s not me. It’s my shadow. It won’t let me be.”

I blink, unsure if I heard him right. Then I notice: his shadow on the linoleum doesn’t match his movements. It lags, then jerks forward, as if fighting some invisible tether. 

“Please,” the old man whispers, “before it’s too late.”

I step back, heart pounding. But the shadow grows, stretching toward me, cold and hungry. I realize I can’t run. Not from this. As the lights flicker and the shadow envelops us both, I wonder if helping him means losing myself entirely.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The cold stone corridor seemed to pulse with each step, shadows leaping away from her lantern’s trembling glow. She pressed her palm against the slick wall, feeling the vibration of distant machinery below. The mechanical thrum was a lifeline, promising that the vault ahead was still sealed. She blinked sweat from her eyes, forcing herself to focus. The pain was growing teeth, gnawing at the base of her skull. But she couldn’t stop. Not with the cipher burning in her pocket and the voices echoing in her memory. At the end of the passage, she saw it: the old iron door, covered in frost and etched with runes. Lore steadied herself, exhaled, and pressed the cipher to the lock. The runes glimmered, the pain in her head sharpened to a point. She whispered the words she’d memorized, and the door creaked open. Whatever waited inside, she was ready. She had to be.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The scent of ozone and damp stone filled her nostrils, grounding her as she advanced along the narrow bridge. Below, the chasm yawned open, swallowing the flickering torchlight in layers of darkness. She heard the distant clatter of chains—a reminder that she was not alone here. For a moment, panic threatened to overwhelm her, but she focused on the promise whispered in the old texts: beyond the eastern gate, the cure awaited. Each step was agony, her head pounding with the rhythm of her heart, but she pressed on. As she reached the ancient archway, the runes carved above it shimmered faintly. Lore pressed her palm to the cold stone, feeling the energy surge up her arm. The pain receded, replaced by a thrumming warmth. The way forward revealed itself, the path glowing with hidden light. Lore took another deep breath, and stepped into the unknown.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. She could feel the heat of the forge radiating through the cavern, the air thick with the scent of scorched metal and ancient dust. Each step was a test of resolve, her vision swimming at the edges. But the memory of her brother’s last words—'you’re the only one who can'—pushed her forward. At the heart of the chamber, the artifact pulsed with an eerie blue glow, chained to a pedestal. She reached for it, fingers trembling, feeling the pain in her head crest like a wave. The world seemed to tilt. She gritted her teeth, pressed her palm to the artifact, and let the energy surge through her. The pain vanished in a burst of cold fire. When Lore opened her eyes, the chains were gone, the artifact was hers, and the way home shimmered before her like a promise kept.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Her hands trembled, and the corridor's damp chill clung to her skin. She could hear the distant drip of water echoing off stone, but she kept her eyes on the sliver of golden light ahead. Each step was a negotiation—between fear and necessity, exhaustion and resolve. When she reached the threshold, she paused, palms pressed against the rough wood of the door. Beyond it, she knew, waited the answer she’d risked everything for. But the voices in her head grew louder, a cacophony of warning and hope. Gritting her teeth, Lore pushed the door open. The room inside glowed with an otherworldly aura. And at its center, the heartstone pulsed, beckoning her closer. Pain forgotten, Lore stepped forward, ready to accept whatever came next.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The flicker of torchlight danced on the ancient glyphs lining the tunnel, casting elongated shadows across her path. She clutched the relic tighter, feeling its warmth pulse in rhythm with her heartbeat. Each step sent a jolt through her body, but she pressed on, determined. At the tunnel’s end, an altar rose from the gloom, draped in tattered banners. Lore knelt, setting the relic atop the cold stone. The pain sharpened, then receded as a gentle hum filled the air. The glyphs shimmered, spinning stories of old across the walls. Lore closed her eyes, breathing in the magic awakening around her. She didn’t know if she’d find the answers she sought, but as the pain faded, she knew she belonged here—at least for this moment, in the hush of ancient power.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The forest pressed in around her, thick with the scent of moss and petrichor. prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text:
Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Kneeling, Lore brushed trembling fingers over the smooth surface. The air thrummed with energy. Shadows shifted in the corners of her vision. She forced herself to focus, tracing the etchings with her thumb. The ground vibrated beneath her knees. She thought of home, of the promise she’d made.

When she finally pried the artifact loose, the pain in her head vanished, replaced by a ringing clarity. Lore stood, the object pulsing in her palm, and for the first time in months, she knew what she had to do. The path forward was uncertain, but as the horizon lit with golden fire, she felt hope rising inside her.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The air was thick with incense and the muffled chanting from behind the velvet curtain. She clutched the silver key in her palm, knuckles white, as she stepped onto the mosaic tiles. She paused before the altar, eyes tracing the gilded patterns winding up the marble columns. The High Oracle waited, shrouded in shadow, her face half-hidden beneath the ceremonial veil. Lore bowed, feeling the weight of a hundred eyes even though the chamber was empty. She raised the key and let it catch the torchlight, a silent offering.

"Are you ready to remember?" the Oracle asked, voice like silk over steel. Lore nodded, voice lost in the cavern of her chest. The key trembled in her hand as the Oracle stepped forward, placing cool fingers on Lore's brow. The pain vanished, replaced by a sudden flood of memories—hers and not hers—swirling through her mind like a storm, rewriting everything she thought she knew.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The tunnel narrowed, forcing her to crawl on scraped elbows through the dust and darkness. Each inhale tasted of rust and ancient secrets. She could hear the quiet ticking from ahead—a mechanical heartbeat echoing through stone.

She remembered her father’s warning: Some doors stay closed for a reason. But Lore pressed on, feeling for the ridges in the wall with trembling fingers. Finally, her hand met cold metal—a lever, just as the map had promised. She hesitated, fear and curiosity warring in her chest. Then she pulled.

Light blazed, blinding after so much gloom. The room beyond shimmered with glass and gears, a clockwork marvel lost to time. And in its center stood a figure, eyes aglow with electric blue, waiting. "You’re late," the figure said, voice impossibly familiar. Lore’s heart hammered. The pain in her head evaporated, replaced by a thousand questions and a single, undeniable certainty: her life had just changed forever.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The package in her coat weighed more than it should. She gritted her teeth and forced herself onward, mind racing through codes and faces, trying to recall who she could trust. The bridge loomed ahead, its shadow stretching long and jagged over the water. She slipped into the current, letting it pull her east, away from the city lights.

Cold seeped into her bones. The pain in her head sharpened, but something else grew stronger: a flicker of hope, stubborn and bright. She reached the far shore, gasping. Behind her, the world burned, but ahead, the woods promised sanctuary. Lore wrapped her arms around herself and vanished into the trees, clutching the future close to her chest.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The scent of ozone stung her nostrils, mingling with the coppery tang of fear. Each step toward the humming portal felt heavier, as if gravity itself conspired against her.

Words of warning echoed in her memory, but she forced herself forward, foot sliding over ancient runes carved into the stone floor. Time stretched, folded, and snapped back. She landed hard on a surface that glowed faintly blue. The world was different—crisp, silent, impossibly still. In the distance, figures in silver robes turned as one to face her, eyes reflecting the same blue light. Lore steadied herself, understanding dawning with the clarity of prophecy: she had crossed into the domain of the First Makers, and everything would change from here.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges.

responses.text:
Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Each step over the damp moss felt like a small victory, the world around her blurring, but the dark shape ahead drawing into sharper focus. The ancient altar, half-swallowed by roots and time, radiated a coldness that made her skin prickle. She remembered the stories—warnings, really—that her grandmother whispered by firelight. But here, now, the stories felt like invitations. 

She reached the altar and pressed trembling fingers to the etched stone. A pulse, slow and shuddering, traveled up her arm and settled behind her eyes. Her offering, a tiny silver locket, trembled in her palm. As she placed it onto the mossy slab, the pain in her head sharpened, then vanished, replaced by a distant, echoing voice. "Welcome, Lore." 

She opened her eyes wide, realizing she hadn't noticed closing them. The forest was watching. And Lore, gasping, realized she wasn't afraid anymore. She was home.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The metallic tang of blood lingered on her tongue, but she ignored it. Her eyes locked on the glimmering shard half-buried in the sand ahead. She dropped to her knees, fingers scraping through grit, desperate to retrieve it before anyone saw. 

Behind her, waves crashed, indifferent and endless. She winced as her hand closed around the shard, warmth pulsing from it into her palm. Instantly, the pain in her head dulled, replaced by a strange clarity. 

"You shouldn't be here," a low voice growled. Lore twisted around, eyes wide. A figure stood silhouetted against the dying sun, their features hidden. 

She wanted to run, but the shard thrummed, anchoring her. "I have to finish what I started," she whispered. 

The figure stepped closer, and the sand beneath Lore shifted, spiraling in unnatural patterns. The pain returned tenfold, but she gritted her teeth. She would not let it win. Not this time.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The cool air of the cavern pressed against her skin, and the faint glimmer of phosphorescent moss illuminated the path before her. Each step sent new waves of ache through her skull, but she pressed on, drawn toward the distant, rhythmic humming that echoed from the heart of the cave.

At last, she reached the source: a crystalline pool, radiating a soft blue light. Kneeling at its edge, Lore dipped her trembling hands into the water. Instantly, the pain receded, replaced by a memory—not her own. Visions flashed behind her eyes: a city of glass towers, voices singing in a language she had never heard. 

She gasped, pulling back. In the reflection on the water’s surface, her eyes shimmered with the same blue light. Something ancient had awakened within her. Lore stood, the humming now louder, resonating in her bones. Whatever waited deeper in the cavern, she knew she would find it. She had to.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The world tilted, the lines between trees and sky blurring in her vision. She focused on the lantern glow ahead, its trembling light her only anchor in the dusk. Behind her, the distant shouts of the search party faded, muffled by the thickening mist. 

She stumbled, nearly collapsing, but forced herself upright. The pain pulsed harder, demanding her attention. Lore pressed a palm to her temple and lurched forward, reaching the lantern’s source: an old woman in a shawl, eyes shining with uncanny brightness.

"You made it," the woman said, voice both kind and chilling. "The headache means it’s beginning."

Lore blinked, confused, but the woman pressed something cold into her hand—a piece of smooth, black stone.

"Breathe," the woman whispered. "Let it in."

Lore did, and as her vision cleared, she realized the pain was not an enemy, but the key. The world shifted. And Lore, for the first time, understood what she was becoming.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The path narrowed, brambles snagging at her sleeves, but she pressed forward, desperate to reach the clearing before nightfall. Her vision pulsed, each heartbeat sending a ripple of dizziness through her skull. 

At last, the trees parted, revealing a ring of standing stones bathed in the dusky gold of sunset. Lore stumbled into the center, dropping to her knees. She unclenched her fist, revealing the tiny glass vial that had called to her in dreams. 

She uncorked it, pouring the shimmering contents onto the ground. The earth trembled, the stones humming in response. Light danced around her, patterns forming in the air. The pain in her head sharpened, then vanished, replaced by a vast, serene emptiness. 

Lore smiled, tears slipping down her cheeks. She was no longer alone. The stones, the earth, the setting sun—all of it was hers now, and she belonged to it in return.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths.

responses.text: A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, carved its values in stone: Prosperity is purity, and poverty is a stain. In the labyrinthine city of Halloway, the sick poor were exiled to the fringes, their existence barely acknowledged. When fever swept through the tenements, the newspapers ran headlines blaming the victims’ "reckless living." Officials gave speeches about "personal responsibility," then closed the hospitals’ doors. As the bodies piled up, those left alive drew murals on the walls, stories of survival and solidarity. They shared the little they had—soup, song, hope. One day, a child painted a ladder reaching skyward, words swirling around: "We are not our illness." The mural drew crowds, first in curiosity, then in shame. A reckoning stirred. Some remembered that sickness is not a sentence, nor poverty a crime. In the end, the abandoned taught the country compassion, not through pleas, but through the quiet persistence of dignity. And the walls, once a barrier, became a bridge.

A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, became a parable for its own undoing. In the cold, gray city of Veridia, the poor learned to hide their coughs, to mask their fevers. The government broadcasted stern warnings: "Health is a choice. Destitution is neglect." As the sick grew weaker, the city’s elite congratulated themselves for their fitness, their wealth. But disease is blind to status. One spring, a new illness swept through the marble halls as easily as the crumbling shacks. When the ministers fell ill, they found the hospitals empty, the doctors gone abroad, the medicine shelves bare. The poor watched in silence as their accusers stumbled through the same shadows. Some offered help; most simply waited. At last, the country saw that blame is a brittle shield against suffering. Those who survived began to rewrite the laws, this time with empathy in the ink.

A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, fostered a culture of suspicion and blame. In the city of Lumen, whispers spread quicker than the illnesses themselves. The healthy distanced themselves, not out of fear of germs, but of guilt by association. Every public square featured screens showing the faces of the sick, with scrolling text: "They chose their fate." In the alleys, Maya tended to her feverish neighbors, risking her own health. She collected stories—the seamstress who lost her job, the old man denied care. Maya wrote these stories in chalk on the city’s walls, where rain could not wash them away. Passersby began to read, then to question. One night, a crowd gathered at the largest wall. Someone added their own story. Then another. The blame began to shift, not onto the sick, but onto the system that let them suffer. Change, slow and uncertain, crept like dawn into Lumen.

A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, believed suffering was a mark of personal failure. In this place, the hospitals had gilded gates and guards at every door. To be poor and ill was to be invisible. Lina, a nurse dismissed for treating the uninsured, joined an underground network of caregivers. By candlelight, she stitched wounds and whispered comfort. Rumors of a 'ghost hospital' spread. Officials, affronted, denounced these acts as "enabling weakness." But the network grew, fueled by the indignation of the forgotten. When a powerful official’s own child fell ill and was turned away, the hypocrisy became impossible to ignore. At last, the country faced its reflection and recoiled. The underground caregivers emerged, not as criminals, but as heroes. A new law was written, born from the shame of a nation that had condemned its own.

A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, was ruled by the Doctrine of Merit. In the city of Ardent, clinics turned away the penniless with icy indifference. The government ran nightly broadcasts: "Health is earned." As the sick languished, a quiet rebellion ignited. A collective calling themselves The Unseen established secret infirmaries in basements and empty warehouses. They left coded messages—chalk marks on lampposts, ribbons on trees—guiding the desperate to safety. The authorities responded with propaganda, blaming the growing death toll on "moral decay." But when a plague swept through even the wealthy districts, the illusion cracked. Citizens demanded answers. The Unseen revealed themselves, exposing the truth on rooftops and billboards: "No life is disposable." The country, shamed, began to mend. Hospitals opened their doors, and the Doctrine of Merit was quietly buried beneath a new creed: compassion for all.

A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths, was wrapped in a veneer of prosperity. In the shadow of towering skyscrapers, Mira, once a teacher, now ailing, watched as friends crossed the street to avoid her. Official posters claimed, "Misfortune is the fruit of laziness." Yet, a group of children she once taught remembered her gentle lessons. They snuck her food, read to her, brought small comforts. Word spread, and an underground network of kindness grew, invisible at first. The government tried to wipe them away, but each erasure was met with ten more paintings. The city transformed, grief turning to solidarity, and the abandoned were no longer invisible. In the end, it was compassion that redrew the map.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: A country that first abandons and then condemns people without money who have the temerity to get sick, accusing them of causing their own deaths.

responses.text: In the nation of Galdora, prosperity had become a precondition for compassion. Hospitals, once bustling with care, now stood as silent monuments to the wealthy. The poor, having been priced out of treatment, were left to fend for themselves. When illness struck the slums, the government responded not with aid, but with accusations. "They are responsible for their own demise," read the headlines. "Their choices led them here." But in the shadows, a quiet resistance grew. Healers and volunteers, themselves shunned by the system, banded together to tend the sick with what little they had. Rumors of their work spread, stories of hope piercing through the condemnation. In time, the country would have to reckon with the truth: abandonment had not killed compassion. It had only forced it underground, where it flourished far from the eyes of those who had turned away.

In the Republic of Mirane, lawmakers declared that all citizens must fend for themselves. Medical care became a privilege, not a right. The destitute, unable to pay, were turned away from clinics and hospitals. Sickness spread among them, and soon, the authorities released a decree: 'Those who fall ill have only themselves to blame.' The state media echoed the sentiment, calling the poor reckless and irresponsible. Public statues honoring 'self-reliance' rose in city squares, while the unwell languished in alleys. But in the shadows, a movement began. Groups of outcasts pooled their meager resources, sharing food and herbal remedies. They wrote letters to distant lands, pleading for help. One day, a foreign doctor arrived in secret, drawn by their courage. Together, they built a hidden clinic—a beacon of defiance in a land of condemnation.

A country once proud of its unity fractured as the wealthy flourished and the poor were forgotten. When a mysterious sickness swept through the land, those without means were left to survive on hope alone. Hospitals closed their doors, politicians washed their hands, and the newspapers blamed the stricken for their 'irresponsibility.' It became law: if you lacked money and fell ill, you were declared a threat to national order—guilty of your own suffering. Yet, in the alleyways and rundown apartments, the condemned clung to each other. They shared what little food they had, passed down old remedies, and whispered stories of better days. One night, a group of them painted a mural on the city wall: a figure reaching out, offering a helping hand. It became a symbol of quiet rebellion—reminding the country that compassion can't be legislated out of existence.

There was a country where the price of survival was counted in coins. Those who had none were left to wither, and when illness inevitably struck, they received not sympathy but scorn. Politicians delivered speeches blaming the sick for their misfortune. 'If only they had worked harder,' they declared. 'Their deaths are of their own making.' But among the shadows of closed hospitals, a different story unfolded. A nurse who had lost her job began tending to the sick in an abandoned church. Word spread, and soon others joined her—outcasts, healers, students. They pooled their knowledge and resources, defying the condemnation heaped upon them. Though the world above dismissed their suffering, below, a new community grew. They did not seek approval, only survival—and in the end, their empathy became a quiet rebellion against the cruelty of the powerful.

In the once-bustling land of Cirelle, a new law swept through the parliament: only those who could afford it would receive medical care. The rest, the government said, must learn to fend for themselves. Soon, the poor huddled in alleys, trading whispered remedies and prayers. When illness claimed lives, the officials declared with chilling certainty, "Their fate is self-inflicted. Their deaths, their own fault." The media echoed these words, shaming the destitute and painting them as burdens. But at the edge of despair, a group of abandoned citizens gathered by candlelight. They shared stories, comforted the sick, and documented every injustice. Their journal became a testament to resilience, and as it spread through the underground, it sparked a quiet revolution—one not of anger, but of steadfast hope in the face of condemnation.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her voice catching on the edge of memory. Outside, rain streaked the windows of the cramped conference room. We all sat in silence, absorbing her words. As a former analyst, she had watched the agency twist in the political winds, watched colleagues whisper in hallways, watched policy shift overnight. 

“Suddenly, everything was about numbers and optics,” she continued. “People became statistics. Each case was a strategy, not a story.”

I glanced at the faces around the table—new hires, old hands, a few like me, somewhere in between. Some nodded, some frowned, but everyone listened. The department had changed, yes, but those changes echoed in every folder we opened, every interview we conducted. 

“Some of us tried to push back. Others left. Most just kept their heads down.”

She looked at us, searching our faces for a different answer. 

“I stayed. Maybe because I thought I could help. Or maybe I was just afraid.”

The rain tapered off. In that moment, I realized the hardest part wasn’t what immigration had done to the department—it was what it had done to all of us.

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, tracing her finger along the coffee mug’s rim. “It made everything brittle. Like glass about to shatter.”

I watched her, unsure whether to interject. The office bustled outside, but inside her small cubicle, the air felt thick. She looked at a photograph pinned to her corkboard: a group of coworkers at a summer picnic, smiles bright and easy.

“Before, we disagreed, sure, but we trusted each other,” she said. “Then the policies came down and trust evaporated. Some people cheered. Others cried in the bathroom. I just tried to keep my head down.”

She hesitated, then continued, “I remember one morning, the ICE agents had to do a sweep. I heard them arguing with the director. One of them said, ‘This isn’t what I signed up for.’ That stuck with me.”

She set her mug down, looking tired. “I still wonder, if we could’ve done more. Or if the machine was always too big.”

Outside, a siren wailed and faded. She turned back to her computer, the conversation already dissolving like sugar in coffee.

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her eyes fixed on the faded badge clipped to her blazer. “It wasn’t just policy changes. It was like a storm—sudden, sweeping, and everyone trying to find shelter.”

Her voice was soft, almost lost in the hum of the fluorescent lights. “People started choosing sides. Some of us, we tried to hold onto the old ways, the sense of duty. But the ground shifted under our feet. We watched good people get reassigned, silenced, or just leave.”

She leaned back, exhaling slowly. “My friend, Javier, he loved this country. He believed in the work. But after the raids started, after the family separations, he stopped coming to lunch. One day, his desk was empty.”

I wanted to ask what happened to Javier, but she just shook her head. “Sometimes I wonder if we could have done more. Or if we were all swept up, powerless.”

A silence settled between us, heavy as snowfall. “That’s how it was,” she said. “That’s what it did to us.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her hands trembling as she organized her notes. “It tore us apart from the inside.”

The conference room was cold, the air tinged with the scent of stale coffee. Her words hung in the silence. “We weren’t just enforcing policy—we were being rewritten by it. Colleagues who’d worked side by side for years stopped speaking. Some cheered each new executive order. Others retreated into silence or left altogether.”

I watched her, trying to imagine what it must have been like. She caught my gaze. “There were days I wondered if we were protecting the country or just building walls between ourselves.”

She drew a shaky breath. “We lost something then. Not just trust in each other, but maybe a piece of ourselves, too.”

The meeting ended. As she left, I realized the story wasn’t about policy or politics. It was about people—and the invisible lines they drew, and sometimes crossed, in the name of homeland security.

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, voice brittle with memory. “It put us under a microscope, but also turned us into strangers to ourselves.”

I sat across from her in the quiet break room, the hum of vending machines filling the space between us. She twisted her lanyard nervously. “Do you know what it’s like to see your colleagues—people you trusted—change overnight? Some became zealots, others ghosts in their own offices.”

She paused, searching my face for understanding. “Policy was one thing, but the fear, the suspicion—that crept in everywhere. Even in the lunch line or the elevator.”

A smile flickered, then faded. “I used to think I belonged here, that we all did. But after those years, I’m not sure any of us recognize this place—or ourselves—anymore.”

The clock ticked on. She gathered her things, and for just a moment, I saw the weight of her story. I left the break room changed, haunted by what had been lost beneath the surface.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her voice echoing in the nearly empty lecture hall. I scribbled notes, but my mind wandered to the old case files stored in the basement. Files that told stories of families separated, of children’s toys left abandoned at border crossings. My aunt, a former DHS agent, used to whisper about the changes—the new policies, the constant tension, the lines drawn between duty and conscience.

After class, I visited her apartment, the walls lined with faded photographs. She sat at the kitchen table, nursing a cup of tea. “It wasn’t always like that,” she said, her fingers tracing the rim of the mug. “The job changed. We changed.”

I pulled out a folder I’d found: a letter from a Guatemalan teenager, thanking her for a kind word during processing. My aunt’s eyes filled with tears. “Sometimes, kindness was all we had left.”

I realized then that history wasn’t just facts and dates—it was choices, made quietly in hallways and holding cells, echoes that linger long after the headlines fade.

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, pausing to let her words settle. The conference room was silent, except for the hum of the projector. On the screen, charts and numbers told stories of policies and procedures, but her voice carried the weight of human experience.

"It fractured us internally. Colleagues who worked side by side for years suddenly found themselves divided—some driven by a sense of duty, others wracked with doubt. We weren’t just enforcing rules; we were living through them. Every day, we wrestled with questions of morality, legality, and compassion."

She looked down at her notes, recalling the faces of families she’d seen, the confusion and fear in their eyes. "We used to talk about security. Now, we talked about lines—who was in, who was out. Even now, those lines are everywhere, invisible but sharp as razor wire."

The audience shifted uncomfortably. She knew it was a story few wanted to hear, but one that needed telling all the same.

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, staring out the window as rain streaked down the glass. “It turned us into gatekeepers, not protectors.”

Her fingers drummed nervously on the tabletop. “I joined to help people. But after 2017, every day felt like a test of conscience. The new protocols changed the way we worked—detentions increased, and we were told to prioritize enforcement over empathy. Sometimes, I’d wake up in the middle of the night, haunted by the memory of a mother clutching her child, begging to stay together.”

A heavy silence lingered between us. I wanted to ask her why she stayed, but the answer was etched in her tired eyes. “Some of us tried to make it better from the inside. But the system was bigger than any one person.”

She sighed, and for a moment, it was as if she was lost to another time, another place. “I hope someday, we find our way back to compassion.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her hands clasped tightly in her lap. “It was like a slow, creeping shadow, changing everything.”

I listened as she recounted stories of late-night raids and hastily rewritten policies. She described colleagues who once prided themselves on fairness now caught in webs of bureaucracy and fear. “We stopped seeing people,” she said quietly. “We started seeing cases, numbers, threats.”

Her voice broke when she remembered the children separated from their parents. “It haunted me. Even now, years later, I still hear their cries.”

The room fell silent, the only sound was the clock ticking on the wall. She looked up, her eyes searching mine for understanding. “We used to believe in protecting the homeland. But somewhere along the way, we forgot that the homeland is made of people. All kinds of people.”

She stood to leave, her silhouette framed by the fading light. “History will judge us. I only hope it remembers those who tried to do right.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her eyes fixed on the rows of empty chairs. “It made us question what it meant to be American.”

She had been an analyst, once proud of her work. But the directives kept coming, each one more severe than the last. She watched as colleagues grew hardened, their jokes turning bitter, their silences heavier. Each morning, she sat at her desk, reading reports about families split at the border, asylum requests denied, and children crying for their parents.

One night, she stayed late, unable to shake the feeling that something was fundamentally wrong. She wrote a letter—never sent—to her supervisor, pleading for compassion, for a return to the values she believed the country stood for. It still sat in her drawer, a symbol of hope and regret.

Now, years later, she tells her story to anyone who’ll listen. “We can’t undo what was done,” she says, “but we can remember. Maybe that’s the first step toward change.”

A clock ticked in the silence. In the corner, a stack of unfiled reports seemed to grow taller. She looked away, her voice barely above a whisper. “It’s still with me. Every day.”

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration," she explained. "It remade the entire department in the image of one policy. Suddenly, everything else was on hold—disaster response, cyber threats, even aviation security. We became a single-issue agency."

Her colleague raised an eyebrow. "But didn’t some people welcome that clarity?"

She shook her head, a faint smile of irony on her lips. "Clarity? Maybe. But at what cost? We lost sight of the big picture. The grind of separating families, the endless briefings about caravans, the pressure to show results. It ate away at us."

She paused, recalling the empty desks of those who’d transferred or quietly resigned. "When you’re asked to ignore your conscience for long enough, the work stops feeling like public service. It starts to feel like something else altogether."

The fluorescent lights hummed overhead. Nobody spoke for a long moment, each remembering the way things used to be.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained.

responses.text:
“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her voice a mere whisper over the hum of fluorescent lights. “It changed everything—priorities, resources, even the way we looked at our neighbors.”

I sipped my coffee, letting her words sink in. The office walls were lined with old reports and photographs, reminders of a time when things felt less uncertain. She glanced at a faded badge on her desk, tracing the outline of the eagle with her finger.

“People forget that policies aren’t just politics. They trickle down, seep into the bones of institutions. We had agents who’d spent decades fighting terrorism suddenly reassigned to border patrol. Morale fractured. Friendships, too.”

She paused, staring out the window at the city skyline. “One day, we were keeping people safe. The next, we were tearing families apart. Some of us tried to speak up, but the machine was too big.”

I wanted to ask her if she regretted staying, but the answer was already in her eyes—haunted, tired, but stubbornly hopeful. The department had changed, but so had she. And maybe, she said, that was the only way forward.

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration," she explained, tracing her finger around the rim of her glass. "It turned the place into a labyrinth. You’d walk in one morning and find your office had moved, or that your badge didn’t work in the elevator. We used to joke that the walls shifted at night."

She leaned forward, her eyes darting around the dim bar. "But it wasn’t just the building. It was the people. Suddenly, everyone was watching each other; teams that used to collaborate started hoarding information. I remember when we’d sit in the break room, swapping stories. By 2019, everyone ate lunch at their desks."

Outside, neon lights flickered in the rain. She lapsed into silence, then added, "For years, I thought I was helping keep the country safe. But by the end, I couldn’t tell who the enemy was supposed to be anymore. Sometimes, I still can’t."

Her laugh was short, brittle. "I left in 2020. Haven’t looked back. But I still dream of that maze."

"That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration," she explained. She looked out the window, watching the rain streak the glass. "It put us at war with ourselves."

I waited, letting the silence settle. She finally continued, "One week, I was reviewing cyber threats. The next, I was standing at the border, clipboard in hand, watching families get separated. Some of my colleagues didn’t sleep for days. Others left altogether."

Her hands shook slightly as she poured another cup of coffee. "The rules kept changing. We’d write up new protocols on a Monday, only to shred them by Friday. Half of us didn’t know what we were enforcing anymore. It wasn’t just the immigrants who got lost in the shuffle."

She gave me a tired smile. "Sometimes I wonder if the department will ever find its way back. Or if we’ve all just learned to live with the confusion."

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained. “It didn’t just shift the mission. It changed the air in the building.”

I watched her gaze drift to the ceiling, as if searching for the right words. “There were always debates, of course, but suddenly, old colleagues who used to share bagels in the break room now avoided each other. There were memos, investigations, endless meetings. Some people were promoted because they enforced the new rules with zeal. Others vanished—transferred to warehouses, or left entirely.”

She sighed. “Sometimes I think about that office on the 8th floor, where we used to keep a plant by the window. After the raids started, someone knocked it over. Nobody picked it up. We just watched it wilt.”

Across the street, a group of children played hopscotch on the sidewalk. She smiled at them. “I used to think our job was to protect. Now I wonder if we just built higher walls.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained, her fingers nervously twisting the hem of her sleeve. “We used to focus on counterterrorism, cyber threats, natural disasters. But after 2017, it felt like everything was about the border.”

She paused, searching for the right words. “They started reassigning agents, shifting budgets. I remember one afternoon, my entire team was told to report to a new task force—no warning, no explanation. Some of us had never even been to the southwest.”

She laughed, but there was no joy in it. “I thought I was helping people. Instead, I was reading detention reports, listening to stories of children separated from their parents. It changed us, all of us. We lost good people, and the ones who stayed… well, we learned to stop asking questions.”

She looked up, meeting my eyes for the first time. “That’s what immigration did. It didn’t just change the rules. It changed the people who enforced them.”

“It changed people, Sarah. The rules, the pressure, the fear—it seeped into every part of the job. We started locking up families, turning away children. Some of us didn’t recognize ourselves anymore.”

Her grandmother sighed, looking out the window as if searching for an answer in the night sky. “I tried, in small ways. A kind word here, a phone call there. But the machine was too big. It ate up compassion and spat out suspicion.”

“That’s what immigration did to the Department of Homeland Security during the Trump administration,” she explained. “It turned us inward, made every decision suspect, every person a potential threat. We stopped seeing names and started seeing case numbers.”

He leaned forward, elbows on the desk. “But did you agree with it?”

She hesitated, memories flickering behind her eyes. “I didn’t recognize the place anymore. It was like the walls themselves grew thicker. The agents who used to joke in the break room stopped smiling. We were told to follow orders, to not ask questions. Some of us did, anyway, and paid the price.”

He scribbled in his notepad. “And now?”

She shrugged. “Now, it’s hard to know what’s left to rebuild. But I’m still here. Maybe that’s something.”
