“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

They waited outside the faded wooden door, shifting from foot to foot, the hallway echoing with distant conversations. Finally, Urueta opened the door, his eyes narrowing as he spotted them.

“Reporters?” he asked, a smirk curling his lips. “You want the truth or just something to print?”

“We’d like your perspective,” I replied, forcing a smile.

Urueta’s gaze lingered. “People always want to listen when it’s too late.”

He gestured us inside. The room was cluttered with old photographs and notebooks. Urueta settled into a battered armchair, lighting a cigarette. He exhaled slowly, words catching in the smoke.

“You won’t like everything I have to say,” he warned. “But if you want the story, you’ll hear it all.”

As he spoke, the veneer of bravado slipped away, leaving a man desperate to be understood. By the end, I realized the real story wasn’t about Urueta at all—it was about what we’d all overlooked.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.” “He doesn’t like us.” “He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.

responses.text:
I waited outside the glass-walled conference room, notebook balanced on my knee, thumb tracing the cover’s edge. Urueta’s voice filtered through the door—a low, rolling cadence, punctuated with exclamation. He was talking to his assistant, and I caught the faintest outline of laughter. “He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking,” I reminded myself, echoing my editor’s voice.

The door swung open. Urueta emerged, his eyes scanning the hallway. “You’re the reporter?” His accent was thick, but friendly. I nodded. He gestured for me to follow, and I trailed him through the maze of offices. “You want the story, yes? Everyone wants the story. But are you brave enough to tell it?”

We sat. I clicked my recorder. Urueta leaned in, his hands folded, gaze intense. “Let me tell you about the night the river changed its course. It started with a single stone…”

By the time he finished, the sun had dipped low, and my notebook was full. Urueta, it seemed, loved talking. He just needed the right story to begin.

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

I repeated the words to myself as I paced the cracked tile outside his office. The last interview had ended with him stalking out, muttering about ‘sensationalist vultures.’ Still, I needed the scoop. 

When the door finally opened, he stood there, arms crossed, eyes wary. “Back again?”

I nodded, trying not to fidget. “Just a few questions, Mr. Urueta. About the night at the port.”

He sighed, looking past me, then motioned inside. “You’re persistent. I can respect that.”

I sat, recorder trembling in my hand. He poured himself a coffee, then fixed me with a sharp gaze. “You want to know why I stayed silent? Some stories are heavier than others.”

His voice softened, and he began, weaving details I never imagined—about the storm, the cargo, and the deal that changed everything. 

By the end, his tension was gone. He’d talked, all right. And I realized he didn’t just love talking. He needed someone to listen.

I stared at the phone, my editor’s words echoing in my ear. “He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.” Easy for her to say. She didn’t have to sit across from the man whose glare could melt steel.

Still, I needed this interview. My story hinged on Urueta’s account, and no one else in town would talk. I steeled myself and walked into the faded café where he held court every afternoon.

He spotted me, his mouth twisting in something like a smile. “You again?”

“Just a few questions,” I said, sliding into the booth.

He drummed his fingers, then leaned forward. “You want the truth? You have to listen. Not everyone does.”

As the hours passed, he shed his armor. Stories poured out—half confession, half warning. By closing time, I had pages of notes and an uneasy feeling in my gut. Urueta hadn’t just given me an interview. He’d given me a responsibility.

I watched the rain streak down the newsroom window, replaying my editor’s words: “He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.” Well, he hadn’t loved talking to me—yet. My last attempt ended with him slamming his office door, muttering about busybodies.

Still, the story wouldn’t write itself. I ducked under my umbrella and walked to the old theater where Urueta volunteered. He was there, sweeping the lobby, humming a forgotten tune.

“Back again?” he called, a smile flickering.

“I just want to hear your side,” I said.

He leaned on his broom, considering. “You’re persistent. Maybe that’s what’s needed.”

Inside, surrounded by velvet seats and moth-eaten curtains, he began to talk. His words danced with shadows—old feuds, lost love, the night he made a choice that changed the city. His story wasn’t just for the paper; it was a confession, a warning, and a hope wrapped in one.

When I left, my notebook was full. Urueta didn’t just like to talk. He needed to be heard.

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.” The words echoed as I waited in the dim hallway, my nerves prickling. I’d seen Urueta’s temper before—how he could flip from charming raconteur to impenetrable wall. I needed this interview, but doubted he’d give it.

The office door creaked. Urueta stood there, arms folded. “You’re still here?”

I nodded. “Just a few questions. Off the record, if you want.”

He hesitated, then gestured me in. The room was cramped, paper-strewn, a single bulb buzzing above. Urueta slumped in his chair. “You want the truth, or a story?”

“Whichever you’re willing to tell.”

He laughed, dry and tired. “They’re not always the same.”

But as the minutes passed, his resistance melted. He talked about the old days, the betrayals, the risks he’d taken. Each word was a stone laid bare.

When I left, I realized: Urueta didn’t just like to talk. He needed to unburden. And maybe, finally, he had.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.” “He doesn’t like us.” “He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.

responses.text:
Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

I tapped my pen against my notepad, waiting for the telltale sound of nervous footsteps in the hallway. Through the frosted glass, his silhouette wavered—tall, angular, hesitant. I nudged the recorder closer to the edge of the table. My editor, across from me, shot a quick glance at the door.

Finally, the knob twisted. Urueta entered, his hands stuffed in his jacket pockets. His eyes darted around the room, lingering on the window, the clock, my pen. Not on me.

“So, what do you want to know?” he said, his voice a careful monotone.

I smiled, trying to make it disarming. “Just your side of the story.”

He sat, exhaled sharply, and then, to my surprise, began to talk. Not just about the event—the scandal that had brought us here—but about his first job, his childhood, the love he’d lost. The story I’d come for faded into the background as Urueta, voice trembling, opened door after door to rooms I hadn’t known existed.

Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

I remembered the last time I’d seen Urueta. He’d been pacing the narrow hallway outside his office, muttering numbers under his breath, fingers twitching with the need for a cigarette. Back then, he’d avoided my gaze, but I’d caught a glimmer of something in his eye—a challenge, maybe, or perhaps an invitation.

When I called this time, his assistant said he was busy. Too busy. I staked out the café across the street, waiting. After two hours, Urueta emerged, coat collar up against the wind, and sat at the corner table. I approached, heart pounding.

He looked up, a tired smile flickering. “You journalists are persistent.”

“We just want the truth.”

He laughed, the tension slipping from his shoulders. “Then let’s talk. But you won’t like everything you hear.”

And as the recorder blinked red, Urueta began to speak, and I realized the real story was nothing like the one I’d come to write.

Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

That was what my producer kept insisting, but at the moment, I was doubting it. Urueta had dodged every call, ignored each email, and once, when he spotted me outside his building, crossed the street without making eye contact. Yet here I was again, at the glossy marble lobby, waiting.

When he finally appeared, he was brusque. “Five minutes,” he snapped, but he didn’t stop walking. I hurried after him, notebook in hand, while he launched into a monologue about city politics, never pausing for my questions. His words tumbled out, sharp and fast, until we reached the elevator.

He pressed the button, then glanced at me. “You getting all this?”

I nodded, breathless. The elevator doors opened, but for a moment, he hesitated. “You want the good stuff? Meet me on the roof in ten.”

The doors closed. I grinned. Maybe Urueta really did love to talk.

Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

But it didn’t feel like love when he slammed the door right in front of my face, leaving me with a head full of questions and a recorder full of static. Still, I waited, pacing the cracked linoleum of the hallway, rehearsing my opening line for the millionth time.

After twenty minutes, the door creaked open. Urueta peered out, eyes narrowed. “Still here?”

“I just want to hear your side.”

He sighed, gestured for me to come in. The apartment was cluttered, papers in teetering stacks, trophies and photographs crowding every surface. Urueta poured himself a glass of something amber and sat heavily on the couch.

“Ask,” he said. “I’ll tell you what I can. But some things—some things you might wish you’d never heard.”

I pressed record. He began to talk, slowly at first, then with growing urgency, his words filling the air like thunder.

Urueta is going to give you the interview you need sooner or later.”

“He doesn’t like us.”

“He got a little tense, but Urueta loves talking.”

That’s what made this all so strange. Every time I tried to schedule, he’d vanish—a ghost in a city of glass towers. But tonight, as I left the newsroom, my phone buzzed: a text from an unknown number. ‘Meet me at the old train yard. Midnight.’

The air was cold and electric when I found him there, standing with his back to the tracks. He didn’t turn as I approached. “You want answers?”

I nodded, recorder ready.

He finally faced me, shadows cutting across his face. “I talk when I want to. Tonight, I want to.”

For the next hour, Urueta told stories—some true, some wild, all wrapped in riddles. I realized, as the sky lightened, that the real interview wasn’t about facts at all. It was about listening to what Urueta chose to say, and what he carefully left unsaid.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August hesitated, staring at the scattered cards on the kitchen table. Each card was a memory, a story, a secret. He picked one up, its edges worn from years of use. "Okay," he said, voice barely above a whisper. "Truth."

Julian grinned. "Alright, what’s the scariest dream you ever had?"

August’s eyes darted to the window, where dusk slipped quietly over the city. He thought of the recurring dream: the endless hallway, doors slamming shut behind him, shadows chasing his footsteps. "There’s this hallway," August began, "and I keep walking, but no matter how fast I go, the doors close. I can’t get out."

The room fell silent. Julian’s smile faded, replaced by something softer. "Do you ever make it to the end?"

August shook his head. "Not yet."

Julian reached across the table, offering a reassuring squeeze. "Maybe next time, you will. And if you want, I’ll be there, too."

In that moment, August believed him.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August took a deep breath, glancing nervously around the circle of friends. The bonfire crackled, casting tall shadows on their faces. He reached for the bottle in the center and gave it a tentative spin. It landed pointing at Lila, who raised her eyebrows expectantly.

“Truth or dare?” she asked, her voice teasing.

August hesitated. “Dare.”

A mischievous grin spread across Lila’s face. “I dare you to tell us what you buried under the old oak tree.”

He stiffened, memories flaring behind his eyes. The others leaned in, their curiosity palpable. August swallowed, recalling the tiny box, the faded photograph, the crumpled letter. He’d thought he’d forgotten it, but now, with everyone waiting, he realized secrets had a way of resurfacing.

“It was something I wanted to forget,” August said quietly. “But maybe it’s time I remembered.”

The firelight flickered, and for the first time, August felt the weight begin to lift.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August stared at the dice in his hand, sweat beading on his brow. The game had taken a turn for the surreal hours ago, when they’d first heard the voice whispering from the attic. But now, as the grandfather clock chimed midnight, the stakes felt real.

"Fine," August muttered. He rolled the dice. A seven.

The attic door creaked open, and a cold draft swept through. Julian smiled, though his eyes darted nervously toward the shadowy stairwell. "Guess you have to go up now."

August stood, his knees trembling. With each step up the stairs, the house seemed to hold its breath. At the top, he paused, hand on the doorknob.

"Remember, you’re not alone," Julian called from below.

August swallowed hard, pushed open the door, and stepped into the darkness—where something waited, just beyond the reach of the moonlight.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August chewed his lip, glancing at the battered chessboard between them. His knight was pinned, his rook cornered, but he reached out anyway, sliding a pawn forward with trembling fingers. "Your move."

Julian studied the board, then looked up. "You’re braver than you think. Most people would have resigned by now."

August smiled faintly. He wanted to tell Julian that it wasn’t bravery, just stubborn hope. The kind that kept him at this table every Friday night, facing defeat after defeat, because in the end, it wasn’t about winning. It was about having someone to play with, someone who noticed when you showed up and when you didn’t.

Julian moved his bishop, trapping the pawn. "Check."

August considered his next move, feeling the warmth of the lamp, the quiet comfort of company. "Not giving up yet," he said.

Julian nodded. "Good. Neither am I."

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August took a shaky breath and looked down at the slip of paper in his hand. The words for the next round of charades were scribbled hastily, barely legible, but he recognized them: "flying pig." Around the room, his friends watched, anticipation gleaming in their eyes.

He stood up, flapped his arms wildly, and snorted, trying his best to look airborne. Laughter erupted immediately, but no one guessed. August hopped in a circle, doing his best pig impression, but only managed to make everyone laugh harder.

Julian finally shouted, "A pig on a trampoline!"

August shook his head, grinning, and pointed upwards, then at his snout. Lila gasped, "Flying pig!"

Cheers erupted. August collapsed onto the couch, cheeks flushed and heart pounding. For the first time that night, he felt like he belonged, his friends’ laughter wrapping around him like a warm blanket.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
August hesitated, glancing down at his trembling hands as the dice rolled between his fingers. The circle of friends around him waited, some with eager grins, others with wary anticipation. He cleared his throat, remembering the dare Julian had given him just moments ago: "Tell us your secret. The one you promised never to say."

He looked at Julian, who raised an eyebrow, daring him to back down. August’s mind raced—should he tell them about the midnight visits to the old greenhouse? About the laughter he heard in the walls? Or the shadow that sometimes followed him home?

Taking a shaky breath, August met Julian’s gaze. "Okay," he said softly. "My secret is... sometimes, I see things that aren’t there. Or maybe they are. I don’t know anymore."

The room was silent. For a moment, August thought he’d made a mistake. Then Julian smiled, a slow, knowing smile. "Welcome to the club," he whispered. All around, the others nodded. The game, August realized, was far stranger than he’d thought.

August drew in a breath, the warmth of the campfire flickering in his eyes. He tried to steady his nerves, feeling the weight of expectation from Julian and the rest of the group. The truth was, he’d never been good at these kinds of games, where stories and truths mixed in the darkness.

He reached for the worn deck of cards in the center. "Alright," he said, forcing a grin, "but let’s make it interesting. Whoever loses this round tells a ghost story."

Julian smirked, always up for a challenge. The cards were dealt, laughter echoing as the rounds flew by. When August lost, he sighed dramatically, everyone scooting closer.

"Fine," August began, voice dropping. "There’s a reason I never go near the pine woods after dusk. They say an old hermit still wanders there, looking for his lost lantern, calling out the names of anyone who dares to listen..."

The fire crackled and, in the shadows, the woods seemed to lean in.

August glanced at Julian, heart pounding. The circle of friends watched him expectantly. He tried to hide his nerves as he fumbled with the bottle in the center of the circle. The truth or dare game had taken a strange turn tonight.

"Okay," August said, voice barely above a whisper. "Truth."

Julian grinned mischievously. "Is it true you went back to the old theater last weekend?"

August’s face flushed. He hadn’t told anyone about that midnight adventure. The echo of footsteps, the flicker of old lights—it had all seemed too unreal to share.

"Yeah," August replied quietly. "I went. And I saw something. Or someone."

The group leaned in, tension rising. Julian’s eyes widened. "What did you see?"

August hesitated, then finally spoke. "A girl in a white dress, standing on stage. She sang my name."

The room fell silent. Outside, the wind howled, as if echoing her ghostly song.

August swallowed, feeling the weight of everyone’s eyes on him. He glanced at the deck of cards fanned out on the table and tried to ignore the way Julian’s gaze pinned him in place. “Alright,” he said, reaching forward. “Let’s see what fate has in store.”

He drew a card, its back marked by a faded red swirl. The King of Spades. Silence fell. Everyone knew what that meant—August was supposed to tell a secret.

His voice trembled just a little as he admitted, “I’ve been sneaking out at night to the old clocktower.” He paused, gauging their reactions. “I thought I was alone, but last time... the gears started moving, even though the clock’s been broken for years. And I heard someone whisper my name.”

Julian’s smirk dropped, replaced with something like nervous curiosity. The others leaned in. Outside, the wind rattled the windowpanes. Inside, the game suddenly felt much more real.

August glared at Julian, knowing he’d been set up. The old game was more than a pastime tonight—it was a challenge. The room fell silent, everyone waiting for his move. He lifted the small, wooden box in the center of their circle and twisted the latch. Inside was a stack of folded notes, each inked with a dare or secret written by one of the group.

August reached in, his hand trembling slightly, and unfolded the top slip. He read aloud: “Face your greatest fear before midnight.”

The air thickened. Julian’s eyes sparkled, almost daring him to back down. August stood, heart racing. The group followed as he slipped through the creaky door and out into the moonlit yard. He approached the old willow tree—where, as a child, he’d seen something he never spoke of.

He paused, then whispered, “I’m not afraid of you anymore.”

The wind stirred. Somewhere, distant laughter echoed, and August realized facing that fear was only the beginning.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted. 

August hesitated, rolling the scarred die between his fingers. The dusty attic was silent except for the distant tick of a clock and the nervous shuffling of their feet. He glanced at the board, where Julian’s piece was three spaces ahead. The game was supposed to be a way to pass a rainy afternoon, but it had taken on a strange tension neither boy could explain.

August inhaled, then tossed the die. It landed on the edge of the faded rug and spun, wobbling before settling on a six. Julian’s eyes widened. “That puts you at the old mirror,” he whispered, leaning closer. 

August moved his token, feeling the air grow colder. The mirror on the attic wall flashed with a silvery ripple. As August’s hand hovered near it, a voice echoed between the dusty beams: “Who dares disturb my slumber?”

Julian’s mouth fell open. August swallowed. “Your turn, Julian,” he whispered, but neither of them moved, both transfixed by the glimmering glass.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August eyed the stack of cards, nerves prickling his skin. The others watched, breath held, as he drew from the pile. Bright red letters spelled out, 'Speak your truth.'

He swallowed. "I... I saw someone in the old greenhouse last night. It wasn't just shadows. There was humming."

The group exchanged glances. Julian gave a crooked grin. "You sure it wasn't your imagination?"

August shook his head. "There was a woman. She looked right at me."

Silence blanketed the room. Then, from the darkened hallway, a faint, familiar tune drifted in—a melody none of them had heard in years, but all recognized from their childhood. The game forgotten, they crept to the door, hearts pounding, and peered into the gloom.

A figure in a tattered dress stood by the window, humming, eyes shining in the moonlight. She smiled, beckoning them forward. The truth, August realized, was far stranger than he could ever confess.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August wiped his palms on his jeans. The circle of flashlights flickered, their beams shaking as the wind battered the tent. He picked up the weathered notebook in the center and flipped to the next dare.

“Tell the group your deepest secret," he read aloud, voice cracking. The others leaned in, breath visible in the cold night air.

August hesitated. He glanced at Julian, who nodded encouragement, then at the others. He swallowed. “Sometimes, I can hear people’s thoughts. Not all the time, but when it’s really quiet, like now.”

Silence fell. The wind howled. Julian tried to laugh it off, but a shiver ran through the group. Suddenly, the tent zipper rattled, and a whisper curled through the darkness: “He’s not lying.”

They all froze, eyes wide, as the shadows outside the tent shifted.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August stared at the old chessboard, the pieces chipped from years of play. He moved his knight, heart thumping. The room, filled with the scent of dust and candle wax, seemed to close in as Julian grinned, pushing forward his queen.

A sudden rumble shook the table. The chess pieces toppled, and the candle flickered violently. The boys exchanged frightened glances as the floorboards groaned beneath them. The queen, lying on its side, began to slide toward a crack in the wood.

Julian reached for it, but August grabbed his arm. "Wait."

From the darkness beneath the floor, a faint, melodic humming drifted up, chilling their bones. They listened, transfixed, as the tune grew louder, the room colder. The game forgotten, they pressed their ears to the floor. What had started as a simple game had become a portal, opening onto something ancient and mysterious below.

I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

August adjusted his glasses and looked at the deck of cards between them. He hesitated, then drew the top card. The candlelight flickered, casting odd shadows on the peeling wallpaper. “It says, ‘Reveal a secret or invite the spirit to play,’” August read aloud, his voice barely above a whisper.

Julian grinned mischievously. “Well? Which is it?”

August swallowed. He glanced at the Ouija board beside them, its planchette already trembling. “Let’s invite the spirit,” he said, almost daring the darkness.

The temperature dropped. The candle guttered, and the planchette glided to the letter ‘H.’ August’s hand trembled. Julian’s grin faded.

“H… E… L… P…”

The air felt thick, heavy with presence. Suddenly, the candle went out, plunging them into darkness. Julian fumbled for his phone, but a cold hand closed over August’s, icy and desperate, pulling him toward the board.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: I know that’s right.” “Your turn, August,” Julian prompted.

responses.text:
August hesitated, fingers tracing circles on the worn Monopoly board. Everyone’s eyes were on him—Julian’s expectant, Charlotte’s kind. He rolled the dice, their clatter loud in the quiet living room. "Six," he announced, moving his thimble past Boardwalk. "Community Chest." He drew a card, reading aloud: "Advance to Go. Collect $200." 

“Nice!” Summer grinned. For a moment, the tension eased. But as August glanced at Julian, he saw the challenge still flickering in his eyes. It wasn’t about the game, not really. It never was, with Julian. 

August pocketed his play money, meeting Julian’s gaze. "Your move," he said quietly, but his words held a new steadiness. The board game continued, but something subtle had shifted. For the first time, August felt like he belonged at that table.

August fiddled nervously with the edge of his card, the fluorescent classroom lights buzzing overhead. "Okay," he said, forcing a smile. "Truth or dare?"

Julian rolled his eyes. "Come on, August, you always pick truth. Live a little."

August glanced at the circle of faces, searching for courage. "Fine. Dare."

A mischievous grin spread across Julian’s face. "I dare you to sing the school anthem—on top of your desk."

For a moment, time froze. Then August pushed back his chair, heart pounding, and climbed onto the desk. His voice trembled at first, but as his friends joined in, the song filled the room, awkwardness melting into laughter. When he hopped down, cheeks flushed, even Julian looked impressed.

August swallowed, his hand trembling as he reached for the deck of cards in the center of the table. The others watched, anticipation thick in the air. He drew a king and set it down with a small smile. 

"Finally," Julian teased, nudging the bowl of popcorn closer to August. "Now you have to answer the question."

August read the slip of paper aloud. "What's the bravest thing you've ever done?" 

The room fell silent. August’s cheeks flushed. "I guess… coming here tonight. Hanging out. I was scared I wouldn't fit in."

For a moment, no one spoke. Then, quietly, Julian nodded. "I know that’s right."

The game moved on, but August felt lighter, the weight of his worry easing just a bit.

August stared at the chessboard, sweat beading along his hairline. His queen was cornered, and Julian’s smirk was growing by the second. He glanced at Mr. Thompson, who watched from his desk, pretending not to notice the silent battle.

Inhaling, August moved his rook, sacrificing a pawn in the process. The room was hushed.

Julian’s eyebrows shot up. “Didn’t see that coming. Nice.”

August grinned, for the first time feeling like he could win—not just at chess, but maybe, just maybe, at fitting in too.

“Check,” Julian said.

August scanned the board. But this time, he wasn’t afraid to play.

August took a deep breath, his heart thumping as he glanced at the circle of faces waiting for him. He reached for the battered bottle in the center, spun it, and watched as it wobbled and landed on Summer. 

He blushed, but managed a shaky smile. “Truth or dare?”

Summer grinned. “Truth.”

August swallowed, remembering Julian’s earlier bravado. “Have you ever wished you were someone else?”

Summer surprised him by nodding. “All the time. But then I remember, everyone’s a little weird inside.”

The group chuckled, and August felt the knot in his stomach loosen. Maybe, he thought, this wasn’t so scary after all.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d line them up each night, careful to give each one a spot near her pillow, whispering goodnight to their glassy, unblinking eyes. The bear with the missing ear was always her favorite, a silent companion through thunderstorms and lonely afternoons. Years later, when the world demanded more of her heart than she thought it could bear, she found herself at a thrift store, running her fingers over the fur of a forgotten rabbit. She bought it without thinking, and that night, nestled among her old collection, it reminded her that loving broken things, even when they couldn’t return it, was a kind of strength she’d known all along.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. In the quiet, moonlit hours, she’d confide her secrets to a faded lion, her fears to a floppy-eared dog. She stitched up their seams when they burst, patched them with scraps of old pajamas, careful not to disturb the fragile stuffing inside. As she grew, the toys gathered dust on the shelf, but she never quite let go. They were her first heartbreaks, her first lessons in patience and forgiveness. Years later, when she found herself comforting a friend who couldn’t return the favor, she remembered the gentle resolve she’d found in the arms of her silent, threadbare friends.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Each evening, she would set them up for a tea party, pouring invisible tea and speaking kindly to each one, even when their button eyes stared blankly ahead. When her parents argued downstairs, she’d clutch her tattered rabbit tight, knowing it would never tell her everything would be okay, but somehow that made her feel braver. As she grew older, she packed them away, but sometimes, in the quiet before sleep, she’d think of them—how love was a gift, not a bargain, and how giving it freely had made her strong.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d assign each one a personality, a favorite food, a secret fear. She’d bandage their worn paws with Band-Aids and tuck them in with gentle fingers, her care unwavering despite their silence. When her best friend moved away, she hugged her teddy bear until her tears dried on its fur. Even as the years swept her into new circles and heartbreaks, she’d catch herself searching for that same uncomplicated comfort, wondering if maybe learning to love something unconditionally was the bravest lesson of all.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She’d spent hours arranging them in elaborate scenes, inventing stories where they rescued each other or braved impossible odds. Sometimes she’d lose one under the bed, and days later, finding it again, she’d apologize softly, as if it could understand. When her little brother arrived, all squalls and need, she was armed with the patience she’d practiced on her silent menagerie. Even now, years later, she keeps one battered bear on her desk, a quiet reminder that the best kind of love is given with no expectation of return.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back.

responses.text: These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Each evening, under the soft glow of her bedside lamp, she’d arrange them in a careful semicircle—a council of silent confidants. Her favorite, a faded blue bunny with one ear lolling, had been through the washing machine too many times to count. She’d press it to her cheek and whisper the day’s secrets, hoping for a twitch of its button nose or a squeeze from its soft, unyielding arms. But the animals never responded, never judged, never left. When her parents’ arguments rumbled through the walls like distant thunder, she held them closer. Years later, as she packed them into a box for college, she realized the love she’d given them had never been wasted. It had taught her patience, resilience, and the quiet beauty of giving without expecting anything in return.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. Lined up on the shelf, from the floppy-eared dog to the threadbare bear, they had silently absorbed her secrets and tears. As she grew older, the world introduced her to other things that couldn’t reciprocate—unanswered letters, distant friends, the ache of longing for someone who never called. When she returned home for the holidays, she found her old plush companions right where she’d left them. She picked up the dog, its fur worn thin, and hugged it tightly. Somehow, loving what could not love you back had made her heart deeper, not harder. She smiled, realizing some affections simply shape us, even if they’re never returned.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. She named each one, gave them personalities, and tucked them in at night, believing they might dream of her kindness. The little brown bear with the missing eye became her confidant, the lion with the crooked mane her brave protector. As years passed, she carried that lesson into the world—caring for stray cats, potted plants, and, eventually, people who sometimes left her messages unread. She learned to love for the sake of loving, not for the promise of return. The stuffed animals gathered dust on her childhood shelf, but she never forgot the warmth they sparked in her chest, a quiet reminder that love’s value doesn’t lie in reciprocity, but in its giving.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. With every tiny sweater she knit, every tea party she hosted, she poured a child’s boundless heart into plush and thread. When their seams split, she patched them. When their eyes loosened, she glued them tight. The animals never spoke, never hugged her back, but her love didn’t need permission to bloom. As she grew, she found herself drawn to lost causes—wilting gardenias, abandoned birds, friends who vanished without explanation. She loved anyway, quietly, fiercely. The stuffed animals remained on her bed, silent witnesses to a heart that never learned to stop giving, even when giving felt like shouting into the wind.

These stuffed animals were how she had first learned to love something that couldn’t always love you back. In the pale morning light, she’d arrange them into careful rows, whispering names and stories into their stitched ears. When her father left, she clutched the ragged fox until her knuckles turned white, waiting for comfort that never came. Over time, she grew to understand that some things—some people—could not, or would not, return her affection. Yet she kept loving, kept tending, kept hoping. The animals remained, their silent presence a testament to her resilience. Years later, she would find herself drawn to causes and people that needed more love than they could give, her heart trained by childhood to persist even in silence.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. The room, shadowed by the amber glow of evening, pulsed with an energy that felt both foreign and familiar. Anna hesitated at the threshold, her heart pounding. She had only seen photos of him, sepia-toned memories tucked in a box beneath her mother’s bed. Now, he stood beside her mother, hand in hand, whispering stories of the past as if he’d never left. Anna wanted to rush forward, to ask a thousand questions, but the air was thick with unspoken truths. She watched as her mother laughed, a sound Anna hadn’t heard in years. Maybe, Anna thought, the past was not as distant as she believed. Maybe, tonight, she could step into it, just for a moment, and finally feel whole.

His father was alive beside her. The rain battered the windows, casting watery shadows across the room. Marcus stared in disbelief as his father reached out to brush a strand of hair from his mother’s face—a gesture he’d only ever seen in fading photographs. Time seemed to warp, the air thick with questions. Was this a dream? A trick of the mind? Or had the storm outside torn open a seam between worlds? Marcus took a hesitant step forward, determined to find out if the impossible could truly stand before him, hand in hand with the woman he thought he knew.

His father was alive beside her. The night air was thick with a strange, humming silence. Elias watched from the hallway, his breath caught somewhere between hope and disbelief. For years his father’s absence had been a wound that never healed, yet here he was, standing beside his mother as if he’d never left. She turned, her eyes glistening with tears and something like relief. Elias stepped forward, the floorboards creaking underfoot, uncertain if this reunion was a miracle or a trick of loneliness and memory. Outside, the old willow tree shifted in the wind, and Elias felt the world tilt toward something new.

His father was alive beside her. Sunlight streamed through the kitchen window, painting everything with a golden haze. The laughter at the table was real, not just an echo from the past. For years, Jonah had tried to fill the void his father left, but now—impossibly—he watched as his parents shared a secret, a smile, a touch. Jonah blinked, wondering if this was a fragile dream that might dissolve with the morning. But his father winked at him, and his mother’s eyes shone bright with joy. Maybe, just maybe, the rules of the world could be bent for a single, precious morning.

His father was alive beside her. The old house was steeped in the scent of cinnamon and dust, yet the air now shimmered with something otherworldly. He watched as his mother’s hand found his father’s, a touch so tender it seemed to rewrite the years apart. No words were spoken, but the silence between them was full—of forgiveness, of longing, of old promises renewed. He stood in the doorway, afraid to move, afraid the vision would vanish if he blinked. But they stayed, solid and real, tethered by love and some ancient, mysterious grace that had finally bridged the impossible distance.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. She’d never imagined this scene: the old man, once so distant, now sitting in the pale morning light at the kitchen table, quietly buttering toast for her mother. The air smelled of oranges and possibility. Outside, the branches knocked gently against the window, as if reminding her that things could still change. He looked up, eyes meeting hers, a hesitant smile breaking through years of silence. "Come sit," he said. She hesitated, memories of arguments and slammed doors flickering in her mind. But his voice, softer than she remembered, pulled her forward. The three of them sat together as the sun rose higher, and for a moment, time folded, letting in the warmth of what could have been. And, perhaps, what might still be.

His father was alive beside her. She stared at the impossible sight, the years of grief and longing crashing inside her chest. He looked older, the edges of his beard silvered, but his eyes—those same stubborn, stormy eyes—met hers with quiet amusement. "I suppose you weren’t expecting me," he said, voice rough with the dust of memory. Her mother reached for his hand, laughter and tears mingling as if no time had passed. Outside, the world continued as always, oblivious to the miracle that had unfolded in their small kitchen. She took a trembling breath, unsure whether to question, to celebrate, or to simply believe. As sunlight spilled across the table, she chose to believe.

His father was alive beside her. The realization struck Thomas like a cold wind; he’d buried that hope years ago, after the accident. Yet here, in the flickering glow of the hospital room, his father sat next to his mother, holding her wrinkled hand as if he’d never left. Thomas blinked, uncertain if he was awake or trapped in some fever dream. The room was filled with a hush, broken only by the distant beep of machines and the soft murmur of his parents’ voices. He stepped forward, afraid the vision would vanish, but his father turned and smiled—a smile that belonged in childhood memories, not this stark reality. It was a second chance he never expected, and he was afraid to take it.

His father was alive beside her. The truth of it unraveled slowly, like a knot easing under careful fingers. Everyone in the village had spoken of his father only in the past tense—lost at sea, presumed gone. And yet, in the dim kitchen, the old sailor’s boots dripped seawater on the floor as he crouched to warm himself by the stove. His mother’s hands shook as she ladled stew, her eyes never leaving the face she had mourned for years. "It was the current," his father murmured, voice rough as gravel. "The current brought me home." And in that moment, the impossible became real, and the world outside their door faded to silence.

His father was alive beside her. Not in body, but in the way her laughter echoed his, in the shape of her hands as she poured coffee, in the stories she retold with his same cadence. Each morning, as the sun crept through the curtains, it seemed his presence grew stronger, woven into the very fabric of her days. He watched her, uncertain whether to feel comforted or haunted, as she moved through the rituals they once shared. Sometimes, he caught her glancing toward the empty chair, lips parting as if waiting for an answer. And though the chair remained empty, his father's spirit lingered, alive beside her, in every unspoken word.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. The memory slipped through the cracks of her mind, drifting in and out like the tide. She could still feel the warmth of his hand, the way he would laugh at his own jokes and wink at her when no one was looking. But now, all that remained was the echo of his voice, a gentle murmur in the room whenever the wind rattled the windows. She wondered if he was really gone, or if part of him lingered in the way the shadows bent around her, in the scent of coffee that sometimes filled the kitchen at dawn. Perhaps, she thought, the line between the living and the memory was thinner than she had ever believed.

His father was alive beside her. She glanced at the old photograph on the mantel, the sepia-tinted smiles frozen in time. But as thunder rolled outside, she could have sworn the man in the picture shifted, turning his gaze to her. The air in the room thickened, humming with a presence she hadn’t felt in years. She reached out, trembling, fingers grazing the glass. The warmth of another hand closed gently around hers. She gasped, heart pounding, and turned to find her son standing there, eyes wide. 'Did you feel that too?' he whispered. In that moment, three generations were bound together, past and present blurring in the storm’s embrace.

His father was alive beside her. The words rang through Michael’s head as he watched his mother’s trembling hands. She had insisted on setting a place for him at the table, pouring a cup of tea as if he would appear at any moment. Michael didn’t have the heart to stop her. As dusk painted the kitchen in amber light, a soft knock came at the door. His mother’s eyes widened with hope and fear. Michael stood frozen as the door creaked open, and a familiar silhouette stepped into the fading sun. The impossible had happened, or perhaps reality had simply bent, honoring a wish too strong to be denied.

His father was alive beside her. In the dim hospital room, Anna reached out, uncertain. The man on the bed, gaunt and pale, opened his eyes and smiled. For weeks, they’d said he wouldn’t wake again, but here he was, fingers lacing with hers. She pressed her forehead to the back of his hand, tears spilling freely. Outside, the world kept spinning, indifferent. But in that small room, time reversed its flow—grief paused, hope bloomed, and Anna understood that every heartbeat was a miracle, every breath a fragile promise. She would not let go, not now, not with life so defiantly present between them.

His father was alive beside her. The realization struck him like a jolt of lightning as he entered the candle-lit room. His mother sat quietly, her hands folded, eyes fixed on the man who, by all accounts, should have been gone. Yet there he was, breathing softly, his chest rising and falling in a gentle rhythm. The silence was dense, punctuated only by the ticking of the old grandfather clock. Outside, rain battered the windows, but inside, an inexplicable calm took hold. He wondered if love could pull someone back from the brink, or if perhaps the universe sometimes bent its rules for the sake of unfinished stories.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. The impossible sight froze Daniel at the threshold, his breath catching in his throat. He’d buried his father in the cold clay of winter, watched the casket disappear beneath the earth. Yet here, in the soft glow of the kitchen, his father laughed gently, brushing flour from his wife’s cheek. They looked up as Daniel entered, their smiles warm and inviting, as if nothing at all was amiss. The scent of baking bread hung in the air. "Come help us," his father said, holding out a hand. Daniel hesitated, the edges of reality blurring, but the comfort of that voice pulled him forward. For tonight, at least, the world could be remade anew.

His father was alive beside her. Mary blinked hard, certain her eyes were playing tricks in the dim hospital room. But there, next to her mother, stood her father, smiling softly, the years of illness erased from his face. Mary’s heart hammered—she’d mourned him, grieved, and accepted his absence. Now he seemed so real, radiating warmth and reassurance. He reached out, fingers brushing her mother’s hair, whispering words Mary couldn’t hear. Suddenly, the room faded, replaced by childhood memories—birthday cakes, laughter, arms pulling her close. When she opened her eyes, she was alone again, but the air shimmered with hope, a promise that love never truly dies.

His father was alive beside her. It was a truth that unraveled everything Tom knew. The old photograph in his hands trembled, the sepia tones revealing more than memory could hold. His mother’s gaze sparkled at the camera, but it was the figure by her side—his father, decades younger, arm protectively around her—that sent a chill through Tom. He had never met the man. Yet, as he studied the image, the room grew colder, shadows stretching. He felt a hand on his shoulder, gentle, reassuring. Spinning around, Tom faced emptiness, but for the first time, he understood—some bonds persist, defying even the boundary of time.

His father was alive beside her. Lila stared, too stunned to speak, as her mother reached for the man’s hand. The last time Lila had seen her father, he was a faded photograph, a memory preserved in silence. Now, he stood in the doorway, eyes brimming with apology and longing. "I never meant to leave," he whispered, voice trembling. Lila’s mother squeezed his hand, her own eyes wet. The world seemed to pause, the air thick with questions and hope. For a moment, grief gave way to possibility, and Lila wondered if forgiveness could be as real as the miracle before her.

His father was alive beside her. The words echoed in Sam’s mind as he rubbed his eyes, unsure if the dawn light played tricks on him. There, at the foot of the bed, sat his father, alive and whole, holding his mother’s hand. After years of absence, of loss and longing, Sam felt both terror and relief. "You’re home," his mother whispered, tears streaming down her face. His father smiled, the lines of sorrow smoothed away. Sam stepped closer, half afraid they’d vanish if he spoke. But they remained, as real as sunrise, and for the first time in years, hope flickered in Sam’s chest.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. The room was dim, sunlight leaking through tattered curtains. She hadn't expected to see him again, not after all these years of silence. He looked older, hair silvered, hands trembling as he reached out for hers. "Why did you come back?" she asked, voice barely more than a whisper. He smiled, a sadness behind his eyes. "For you. For the things I left unsaid." The clock ticked between them, time stretching the space of forgiveness. Outside, the world carried on, oblivious to the reunion within. In that moment, old wounds softened, and hope flickered anew.

His father was alive beside her. She blinked, unable to reconcile this reality with the faded photograph she carried in her wallet. He turned to her, eyes gentle and filled with regret. "I never meant to leave," he said, his voice trembling. The shadows in the room seemed to listen, holding their breath. She searched his face for answers, for the years lost to secrets. In that fragile moment, forgiveness hovered, uncertain, between them – a chance for new beginnings, or a final letting go.

His father was alive beside her. The words hung in the air, almost unbelievable after so many years of thinking him gone. She traced the lines on his weathered hand, memories flickering like candlelight. They sat in silence, the only sound the rhythmic ticking of the old wall clock. Outside, the world seemed unchanged, but inside, everything was different now. His eyes met hers, full of stories left untold, and she realized sometimes the past returns not for closure, but for a second chance.

His father was alive beside her. For a moment, time itself seemed to bend, all the memories and grief swirling around them. She could hardly breathe, uncertain if this was a dream or a cruel trick of the mind. But then he smiled, that same gentle smile she remembered from childhood. "It's really me," he whispered. Tears welled in her eyes as she reached out, her fingers trembling. In the hush of the twilight room, the impossible had become real, and with it came the hope of healing.

His father was alive beside her. The hospital monitors beeped steadily, grounding her in the present. She had braced herself for goodbyes, not reunions. His hand found hers, calloused and warm. "I never thought I'd see you again," she said, voice cracking. He squeezed gently, eyes glistening with unshed tears. "We have more time," he whispered. Relief and disbelief tumbled together, and she let herself hope that, perhaps, the past could be rewritten, just a little, in the time they had left.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: His father was alive beside her.

responses.text: His father was alive beside her. The flicker of the old lamp cast monstrous shadows, but she sat unmoving, hands folded tightly in her lap. He had known his father to have been gone for years; the photos faded, the voice a memory. Yet here he stood, watching the impossible reunion. His father reached for her hand, eyes brimming with stories untold. She looked up, not startled, but as if she’d been waiting for this visit all her life. The air shimmered with words unspoken, forgiveness hovering just above their heads. Outside, the world continued, unaware that time itself had bent for love to return, just for a moment, to say goodbye.

His father was alive beside her. She pressed her trembling hand to his chest, feeling the steady thrum of his heart. The doctors had all given up, but here he was, sitting upright, cheeks flushed with life. Outside, a storm battered the windows, as if the world tried to reclaim what it had lost. He opened his eyes and smiled, a gentle, bewildered smile. "Did I miss much?" he whispered. She shook her head, tears slipping past her smile. The impossible had happened; hope, it seemed, could weave its way back from the farthest edge of despair.

His father was alive beside her. She didn’t flinch, though the room felt colder than it should. The clock ticked furiously, marking time as if it wanted to convince them of its authority. But for now, time lost its grip. His father smiled gently at her, his eyes the same stormy blue as always. She reached out, uncertain, and her hand passed through him like smoke. Still, his presence lingered, filling the silence with memories, forgiveness, and a warmth that, though fleeting, was enough to carry her through the night.

His father was alive beside her. The realization struck him like a wave as he entered the sunlit kitchen. There he was, humming an old tune, hands moving deftly as he chopped vegetables. She, his mother, watched with a quiet joy, her eyes shining in a way he hadn't seen in years. How was this possible? He blinked, half-expecting the vision to dissolve. But the sharp aroma of onions, the sound of laughter, all felt real. Maybe, just for today, the past and present had decided to intertwine, gifting them a moment outside of time.

His father was alive beside her. The hospital room, usually bleak, now buzzed with an energy he couldn’t explain. His mother’s face was radiant, illuminated by the afternoon sun, while his father—pale but smiling—reached out to clasp her hand. A miracle, the doctors would say. But for him, it was something more: a second chance. He watched them, the way they fit together even after years apart, and knew that sometimes, the universe bent its rules for love. He closed his eyes, letting the warmth of their reunion wash over him, grateful for the impossible.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The city outside had fallen silent, save for the distant wail of sirens and the soft patter of rain on the cracked windows. Thomas crept down the deserted hallway, his heart pounding in his chest, eyes darting toward every shadow. The memo had been clear: everyone out by midnight. But Thomas wasn't everyone. He’d hidden in the janitor’s closet, waiting. Now, with the power flickering and the elevators dead, he knew something was wrong. The thud of heavy footsteps echoed from the stairwell. Thomas pressed his back against the wall, praying they would pass. Instead, the footsteps halted outside the door. The knob twisted, slowly, and a voice whispered, “You shouldn’t be here.” Thomas recognized the voice—the one he never thought he’d hear again. He took a shaky breath. "Neither should you," he replied, as the door creaked open.

He was still in the building. The fluorescent lights flickered and hummed, casting pale shadows over the empty cubicles. Daniel held his breath and crouched behind a desk, clutching the paper he’d risked everything to retrieve. Outside, thunder rolled. The security guards had made their rounds, convinced the place was empty. Daniel waited, counting each second, until he heard the elevator ding. Someone else was in the building. Panic flared. He peeked over the desk, spying a dark figure moving with purpose. They stopped at the exit, glancing at the security camera. Daniel realized, with cold horror, the cameras were never off. The entire time, someone had been watching, waiting, and now they were coming for him. He pressed the paper to his chest, praying it had been worth it, as the lights snapped off, plunging him into darkness.

He was still in the building. The others had left hours ago, their laughter fading down the stairwell, but Leon lingered. The deadline loomed, and he was determined to finish, no matter the cost. He typed furiously, the only sound in the cavernous office the staccato rhythm of his keyboard. Then, a faint tap echoed from the conference room. He froze. The cleaning crew never came this late. Leon stood, edging toward the noise. The tap became a knock, rhythmic and insistent. He opened the door to find a single envelope on the table, addressed to him in looping script. Inside, a single sentence: “You are not alone.” Leon’s breath caught. He turned, but the hallway was empty. The building creaked, settling, or perhaps…something else. He gathered his things quickly, vowing never to stay so late again.

He was still in the building. The evacuation alarm had blared nearly an hour ago, sending his coworkers rushing for the exits, but Peter lingered in the archives. He’d waited years for this chance, and wasn’t about to lose it to a false alarm. The documents he sought were buried deep in the restricted files, and with trembling hands, he finally found the folder marked “Project Bellwether.” The silence pressed in, broken only by the distant groan of settling concrete. As Peter leafed through the pages, a sudden chill swept the room. He turned, expecting to see the night guard, but the corridor was empty. Then, the door slammed shut, locking him inside. Peter’s heart raced. On the other side, footsteps approached, slow and deliberate. He realized too late—he was meant to be found.

He was still in the building. The old clock tower chimed two in the morning, its echo bouncing through the marble corridors. Ben pressed himself into a shadow, listening for any sign of pursuit. The heist had been going flawlessly—until the silent alarm triggered. Now, with the artifact tucked under his coat and the security team combing the halls, Ben had only one option: up. He scaled the winding staircase, breathless, each step bringing him closer to the rooftop. Behind him, shouts rang out. He reached the final door, only to find it locked tight. As the footsteps neared, Ben weighed his choices. The storm outside raged, but freedom lay beyond the ledge. With a final glance at the ancient idol in his hands, Ben made his decision and leaped into the night.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The emergency lights flickered, casting long shadows across the marble floor. Nathan pressed himself against the wall, listening for the echo of footsteps—friend or foe, he couldn’t tell. He had lost his phone in the scramble, and now the only way out was the stairwell at the end of the hall. But as he approached, a metallic clatter rang out above him. Heart pounding, Nathan ducked into an empty office, squeezing behind a desk. He waited, breathing shallowly, as the footsteps drew closer. The handle turned. Nathan braced himself, unsure if the next few seconds would bring rescue or danger.

He was still in the building. The storm outside raged, rattling the windows and drowning out the city’s usual hum. Julian wandered the empty corridors, the echo of his footsteps his only companion. He checked his watch—midnight. With a sigh, he pushed open the door to the old library, where the scent of musty books mingled with the metallic tang of rain. He’d come searching for answers, but each page he turned whispered more questions. As lightning illuminated the stacks, Julian realized he wasn’t as alone as he thought. A shadow flitted past—a memory, or something far more tangible?

He was still in the building. The security guards had swept through twice already, their flashlights slicing through the darkness, but somehow he’d managed to avoid them. Now, crouched behind a row of dusty filing cabinets, he waited for the perfect moment to make his move. His heart thudded in his chest, loud enough he feared it might give him away. All he needed was a few more minutes, just enough time to retrieve the folder that would prove everything. But as the minutes dragged on, the silence pressed in, and he wondered if he’d underestimated just how alone he really was.

He was still in the building. Hours had passed since the others left, and the silence was as thick as the dust motes swirling in the shafts of moonlight. He wandered from room to room, searching for something—he wasn’t sure what. Maybe a clue, maybe a memory. In the boardroom, he paused, drawn by the faint glow from a forgotten laptop. On its screen, a single sentence blinked: “Don’t forget why you came.” Chills ran down his spine. He glanced over his shoulder, suddenly aware of the weight of every secret the walls had seen.

He was still in the building. The ventilation system hummed above, a constant reminder that for all its emptiness, the place was not entirely dead. Alex crept along the corridor, flashlight beam trembling over peeling wallpaper. He didn’t know what he was looking for—only that he had to find it before anyone else did. A door stood ajar at the end of the hall. He hesitated, then pushed it open. Inside, the air was colder, the silence deeper. Something glittered on the floor: a single silver key. As he reached for it, the door swung shut behind him.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The echo of distant footsteps sent ripples through his nerves as he pressed his back against the cold marble wall. He’d thought everyone had left hours ago—the lights beyond the atrium were all out, the janitorial cart was abandoned, and the elevators had stopped humming. He clutched the folder tight, its contents more precious than gold, and inched toward the emergency stairwell. A sudden click echoed behind him. Heart pounding, he swallowed hard and peered around the corner. The red exit sign flickered above, but a shadow blocked its glow. He recognized the silhouette instantly. It was supposed to be a routine pickup, but now it was a game of survival. He had to get out, now, before the shadow found him first.

He was still in the building. The city outside was a blur of neon and rain, but inside, the silence was thick, broken only by the dull hum of the vending machine in the hallway. He crept forward, shoes leaving faint prints on the polished floor. There, in the conference room, the evidence waited. He’d spent months preparing for this moment, but now, with every step, doubt gnawed at him. Did they know? Was this all a trap? He reached for the door, hand trembling, and as he turned the knob, a voice whispered from the darkness, "You shouldn’t be here."

He was still in the building. That realization came with a wave of panic as the lights flickered overhead. He pressed himself against the wall, straining to hear any sound beyond his own ragged breathing. The last text from his contact had been cryptic: "Don’t trust anyone. Meet me at the archives." But the archives were three floors down, past security cameras and locked doors. As he edged toward the stairwell, he heard a low, metallic clang—someone, or something, was coming. He braced himself, clutching the small flash drive in his pocket, and prayed he’d make it out before sunrise.

He was still in the building. The clock on the wall glowed 2:17 AM, casting a blue halo through the gloom. He hadn’t meant to stay so late, but the files wouldn’t reconcile themselves. As he packed his bag, a loud crash echoed from the floor above. He froze, heart thumping. Was it just old pipes, or something else? He thought about the stories—strange noises, flickering lights, the janitor who’d quit without notice. He tiptoed to the stairwell, but the door handle was icy cold, almost sticky. He hesitated, then pulled. The door creaked open, revealing darkness. He took a step forward, and the door slammed shut behind him.

He was still in the building. The storm outside rattled the windows, and all the others had left hours ago. He made his way down the deserted hallway, each step echoing off the tiled floor. He paused by the elevator, but its doors remained stubbornly closed. Something felt wrong—he couldn’t shake the sensation that he wasn’t alone. A shuffling sound came from the break room. He swallowed, steeling himself, then pushed open the door. The room was empty, save for a single, flickering light. On the table, a note: "We know you’re here." His blood ran cold. He turned to run, but the hallway behind him was no longer empty.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The echo of his footsteps reverberated through the marble halls, bouncing off faded portraits and shattered glass. He pressed his palm against the peeling wallpaper, searching for the hidden switch his grandfather had described so many years ago. As the sirens wailed outside and the red glow seeped under the heavy doors, he wondered if the secrets buried here were worth the risk. His breath came faster now, mixing with the dust in the air, but he refused to turn back. Somewhere ahead, a faint chime sounded—three notes, like a lullaby. He squared his shoulders and stepped forward, certain that if he left now, he'd never find the answers he’d come for.

He was still in the building. The fire alarm had been blaring for fifteen minutes, but he couldn’t bring himself to leave. Somewhere in the mess of toppled chairs and scattered papers was the envelope—his entire future. He ducked beneath the smoke, coughing, his eyes stinging. Every instinct screamed at him to escape, but the thought of walking out empty-handed was worse than the flames. Finally, his fingers closed around the crumpled envelope just as the ceiling groaned. He ran, heart pounding, and burst through the exit into the night, clutching his hopes against his chest.

He was still in the building. The others had left hours ago, laughter fading down the stairwell, but he lingered in the fluorescent haze of the empty office. The city lights flickered beyond the window, casting strange shadows on the walls. He listened to the hum of the vending machine and the distant thrum of traffic, feeling for a moment as if he might dissolve into the silence. Somewhere, a phone rang, muffled and insistent. He hesitated, then picked it up. A voice whispered, "I know what you did." The line went dead. He stared at his reflection in the glass, suddenly unsure if he was alone after all.

He was still in the building. The sensation was strange, almost dreamlike—he watched the janitor lock the doors, unaware of the presence lurking in the shadowy alcove. He pressed himself against the cold tile, silent, unseen, waiting for the perfect moment. The world outside faded into irrelevance; all that mattered was finishing what he’d started. When the lights went out and the only illumination came from the moon through the skylight, he crept forward, holding his breath. In the stillness, every sound seemed magnified. He wondered if he’d ever step outside again, or if the building would become his tomb.

He was still in the building. The clock above reception had stopped at 3:17, the exact moment the power failed. He wandered through the corridors, guided only by the faint glow of emergency lights and the memory of how things once were. A distant thud echoed from the basement, and he hesitated—was it just the old pipes, or something more sinister? He moved closer, each step muffled by the thick carpet. As he reached the stairwell, the air grew colder. He tried to remember why he’d stayed so late, but all he could recall was the strange, urgent voice that had whispered his name from the darkness.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The echo of hurried footsteps reverberated down the empty marble halls as the last of the staff rushed to leave for the night. Marcus pressed himself against the cool stone wall, barely breathing, listening to the muffled clatter of keys and the distant click of the front doors being locked from the outside. He had to find it before they did. With only the flickering light from his dying flashlight, Marcus crept toward the forbidden wing, heart pounding in his chest. Shadows danced along the ornate wallpaper, and every creak of the old floorboards threatened to betray his presence. Somewhere in this labyrinth of offices, the truth was hidden—a secret that could change everything. As he reached the heavy oak door marked "Archives," Marcus hesitated, then gripped the handle. The door swung open with a groan, and he slipped inside, determined to uncover what had been buried for so long.

He was still in the building. Somewhere above, the janitor’s cart squeaked across the linoleum, but in the basement, all was silent except for the soft hum of the old generator. Isaac crouched behind a stack of file boxes, clutching the faded photograph that had drawn him back to this place. The edges curled with age, the faces smiling out at him, oblivious to their fate. He had to know what happened that night—why the records were sealed, why no one spoke of the fire. The air was thick with dust and secrets. As he scanned the dimly lit shelves, a chill crawled up his spine. In the far corner, a shadow moved. Isaac froze, heart thundering. He was not alone. The past, it seemed, was still very much alive.

He was still in the building. The storm outside lashed the windows, rain drumming like frantic fingers. Lucas crept through the labyrinthine corridors, the emergency lights casting long, trembling shadows. He glanced over his shoulder, certain he’d heard breathing that wasn’t his own. Every door he passed seemed to whisper his name, urging him on or warning him to turn back. At the end of the hall, the elevator doors stood ajar. He hesitated, remembering the stories about the old hotel: guests who checked in but never out, staff who vanished without a trace. Lucas squared his shoulders and stepped inside. As the doors slid shut, the lights flickered, and a chill settled over him. The building was waiting.

He was still in the building. No one else knew—at least, not yet. Evan pressed his back to the peeling plaster, listening for the distant elevator chime. The plan had been simple: grab the files, get out before midnight. But nothing ever went according to plan. Somewhere on the twelfth floor, a phone rang, its shrill cry echoing through the empty corridors. Evan’s pulse quickened as he realized he wasn’t as alone as he’d hoped. The documents he clutched were heavier than paper; they were loaded with promises, threats, and secrets. He took a deep breath, steeled his nerves, and headed for the stairwell, every step a gamble in the silent, watchful dark.

He was still in the building. The after-hours silence pressed in around him, broken only by the hum of fluorescent lights and the ticking of his watch. Daniel moved cautiously, avoiding the security cameras he’d mapped out earlier. His mission was time-sensitive, and he could almost feel the weight of the envelope in his pocket burning against his skin. Somewhere above, the elevator dinged, and Daniel ducked into a supply closet, holding his breath. He could hear footsteps—slow, deliberate. The plan was unraveling, but retreat was not an option. As the footsteps paused outside the door, Daniel braced himself, wondering if the secrets he carried were worth the risk he’d taken to stay.

prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: He was still in the building.

responses.text: He was still in the building. The echo of alarms faded behind him, replaced by the haunting click of his shoes on the marble floor. He pressed himself against the wall, heart pounding in his chest, listening for any sign of pursuit. The blueprints had promised a secret exit behind the old library, but now, in the shadows, every hallway looked the same. A muffled cough echoed from down the corridor. Holding his breath, he slid silently toward the heavy wooden door, praying the handle wouldn’t squeak. As he opened it, moonlight spilled over stacks of forgotten books. Relief washed over him—until he saw the silhouette waiting by the window, a gun glinting in her hand. "You took something that doesn’t belong to you," she whispered. He raised his hands, the artifact hidden in his coat pocket suddenly feeling heavier than ever.

He was still in the building. The realization struck him with a surge of dread as he crouched behind a toppled filing cabinet. The city outside had gone dark, but inside the emergency lights cast everything in a feverish red glow. He clutched the torn photograph tighter, the only clue left about his brother’s disappearance. Footsteps approached—measured, deliberate. He didn’t dare breathe. When the footsteps paused, he risked a glance through the crack. A figure in a security uniform scanned the darkness, flashlight wavering. He waited, every muscle trembling, until the guard moved on. He needed to get to the seventh floor. Whatever was waiting for him up there had to be worth the risk of staying behind, alone, in a building that seemed to pulse with secrets.

He was still in the building. The evacuation notice had sounded almost an hour ago, and yet, for reasons he couldn't quite articulate, he lingered among the empty cubicles and humming servers. Shadows stretched across the linoleum, and he traced his fingers along the desk where he'd spent so many late nights. A distant clang echoed from the stairwell, and he tensed. Was it the maintenance crew, or someone—or something—else? He hesitated, then made his way toward the records room, drawn by a strange compulsion. Maybe it was the unfinished work, or maybe it was the magnetic pull of a secret that waited just behind the locked door. Either way, he knew that tonight, he would finally uncover what the others had been so desperate to hide.

He was still in the building. The automatic doors had sealed with a hiss, trapping him inside with the flickering lights and the acrid scent of smoke. He pressed the emergency call button, but the only answer was static. In the distance, he heard the faint whirring of the security drones, scanning for movement. His briefcase felt impossibly heavy as he crept along the corridor, trying to recall the layout from memory. He had seen something he shouldn’t have—on the 13th floor, behind the glass wall—and now he was certain they knew he was here. As the footsteps grew louder, panic surged through him. He ducked into a supply closet, heart hammering, and hoped that, somehow, he’d find a way out before morning.

He was still in the building. The others had left hours ago, their laughter fading into the night as he pored over blueprints in the empty office. At first, he thought the creaks and sighs of the old structure were nothing more than the usual settling, but then he heard the unmistakable sound of footsteps. He stood, the paper in his hands trembling. The footsteps stopped outside his door. A soft knock, then silence. He backed away, breath shallow. The door handle turned slowly, and in the gap he saw a figure—face obscured, holding a small, flickering candle. "We’ve been waiting for you," the stranger whispered, voice echoing strangely. He realized then that leaving was no longer an option.
